business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, pursuant to standing order 154, I move:

debateinfo.title: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1999

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Ellison, at the request of Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Ellison) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) was established by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989. ATSIC began operations on 5 March 1990. ATSIC gives indigenous people a voice in the processes of government.

Its representative arm consists of 35 Regional Councils on the mainland and Tasmania, and the Torres Strait Regional Authority. Every three years, indigenous people vote in Regional Council elec tions. Their elected representatives consult with local indigenous communities about programs and policies affecting them, and represent their interests to the ATSIC Board.

ATSIC Regions are incorporated into zones. There are 16 zones, and the Regional Councillors in each zone elect one of their number to be on the ATSIC Board—their zone Commissioner. There is also a zone Commissioner from the Torres Strait, elected by members of the Torres Strait Regional Authority. To date, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has also appointed the Chairperson, and one other Commissioner. This provision in the ATSIC Act was amended in 1996, to provide that the Commission consisted of only elected representatives, and that the ATSIC Chairperson be elected by the Commissioners from amongst their number. This amendment to the act will apply after the forthcoming ATSIC zone elections which will follow the ATSIC Regional Council elections scheduled for 9 October 1999. It is expected that the elections of zone Commissioners will take place in early December 1999.

Madame President, I pay tribute here to the achievements of the founding Chairperson, Dr Lowitja O'Donoghue, and the current Chair, Mr Gatjil Djerrkura. Both are widely respected and admired for their significant contributions to indigenous affairs in Australia.

The bill before the Senate today does not include any major changes to the ATSIC Act, but it is important in that it clarifies the process pertaining to the new arrangements for the Chairperson. The bill provides that the person elected by his or her fellow Commissioners to be the ATSIC Chair ceases to hold his or her original offices of Regional Councillor and zone Commissioner. The positions left vacant by the election of the Chairperson will be filled through the processes set down in the election rules made under the ATSIC Act. The indigenous people in the affected region do not have to vote again—a recount is done to elect the new Councillor. In the case of the vacant position of zone Commissioner the Regional Councillors will elect a new Commissioner in a by election. This process results in a Commission of 18 members, rather than the 19 currently.

To ensure that the number of Commissioners should equal the number of zones, plus one (the Chairperson), the bill also provides that a Chairperson who resigns is also taken to have resigned as a Commissioner. The bill removes the current reference to 17 members in section 27 of the act and clarifies that the Minister must appoint as members of the Commission those persons elected to represent the several zones.
The bill will commence when Commissioners take office after the zone elections in approximately December 1999.
There are no financial implications arising from this bill except that the person who fills the vacant offices of Commissioner and Regional Councillor will be entitled to salary and allowances.
I commend the bill.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned till the first day of the 1999 summer sittings, in accordance with standing order 111.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10 August, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday I addressed the Senate in reply to the second reading debate on the bill before the chamber, the Constitution Alteration (Establishment of Republic) 1999 , and I would like to clarify for senators the fact that we do not have the Presidential Nominations Committee Bill 1999 before the chamber. We are debating the bill which will in effect deal with the referendum on 6 November, and without the passage of that bill the referendum cannot take place. Consequential to any move to a republic is the passage of the Presidential Nominations Committee Bill 1999, which I have mentioned. I note that Senator Brown has moved amendments to the Presidential Nominations Committee Bill, but that bill is not before us at this time.

speech.para: I can say, however, that the government has considered its response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Republic Referendum, and in that report there were recommendations in relation to the Presidential Nominations Committee Bill 1999. The government proposes tabling its response, which sets out the government's attitude to those recommendations of the joint committee which deal with the Constitution Alteration (Establishment of Republic) 1999 and with the Presidential Nominations Committee Bill 1999. We are covering two pieces of proposed legislation—one which is before the Senate and one which is not—but we want to be able to tell the Senate and the community what we as a government will do in the event that we move to a republic on 6 November this year.

During the course of the committee stage in the debate of this bill it would be useful if we canvassed the Presidential Nominations Committee Bill as well. This is not an usual procedure, but we are dealing with something that is quite extraordinary—namely, a referendum dealing with whether this country should become a republic. There is nothing untoward about this; it is simply a matter of procedure and a matter I wanted to draw to the attention of senators. At the conclusion of my reply I will seek to table the government's response.

As well as that, I draw to the attention of senators the fact that the research which I mentioned in my speech last night was tabled. That was made public previously, but nevertheless it was thought appropriate to table it yesterday so that anyone who did not have a copy of it could obtain one for the purposes of the ensuing debate.

The government has amendments which I believe have now been circulated in the chamber. These amendments relate to the Constitution Alteration (Establishment of Republic) 1999 , which is the bill before us.

I conclude by once again thanking senators for their contributions yesterday and stressing to the Senate that the government is approaching this in an open-handed and objective manner and that it intends to engage in a full campaign to educate the community in relation to aspects of our current system, the proposed changes and the procedure of the referendum. We are taking on board the comments made in relation to informing the public. We realise from our research that there is some work to be done—approximately half those people surveyed said that they needed more information. More particularly we will be looking at those sectors of the community with a non-English speaking background, particularly Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. I conclude with those remarks, and I table the government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Republic Referendum.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The bill.

talk.start.para: —Madam Chair, before we commence the committee stage debate, can I ask for the cooperation of the committee in relation to the general issue of the handling of the committee stage debate. It goes to the issue of when we might deal with the question of the long title of the bill. You might seek advice on this, but I certainly understand that the issue of the long title may well in the ordinary course of events be dealt with at the conclusion of the committee stage of the debate. Given that the Senate standing orders are clear on that point, the point I would like to make to the committee in a general sense before we commence the committee stage debate is that we do have a circumstance here where the long title actually informs the debate. I think from all sides of the chamber and all sides of the argument there would be general agreement about that. It does seem to me in this instance that we might look, either with leave of the committee or with cooperation of those participating in the committee stage debate, that on this occasion, in the interests of facilitating the debate, we deal with the question of the long title first. I do not want to place that procedural conundrum before you so early in the day—
—I have an answer, Senator.
—Thank you. But I think most senators agree that it is an important threshold issue before we move into more general debate in the committee.

—Standing orders require that the title is normally the last item dealt with in the committee stage. However, it is up to the committee itself, if it is the wish of the committee, to deal with the amendments and the issues in whatever order it so wishes. If the committee wishes to deal with the title first then, if there is leave to do so, the bill having been taken as a whole, it can be done. We do now have a running sheet, too, I am told.

—I would endorse the process that Senator Faulkner has just outlined, Chair. I think it is sensible. As Senator Faulkner says, the long title does inform the debate. It is central to the debate that is going to ensue. I am trying to just work this out. It is a matter of really determining at the outset what the question will be at referendum in so far as this committee is concerned and then we get on to debating the rest. The long title of the bill is in effect the sentence that will be put on the referendum papers, so it is very important that we clear that up first. Senator Faulkner is quite sensibly saying that we should do that instead of as normal at the end as a very last question in the committee deliberations, which could be sometime tonight or tomorrow. It is much better that we know what we are dealing with right now at the outset. I think it is a sensible move and I will certainly be granting leave, if that is what is required.

—I take the view that the long title should be dealt with in accordance with what is in the standing orders. It is there for a very valid reason in the standing orders. I have seen amendments to legislation go through the committee stage which really do have an effect on those of us who are considering the long title at the end of the legislation. To deal with the long title at this point in time is, in my view, premature. There is quite a large number of amendments which we need to be considering and I do not think it is appropriate or practical, to be quite frank, to deal with the long title right now. I would suggest that it would be better to deal with the long title, if it is inadequate, having regard to amendments that are made to the legislation. Let us do it at the appropriate time, informed as we will be of what the general desire of the chamber is.

—This is slightly at a tangent but I think still relevant to the order we deal with the amendments in. We have now got an initial incomplete running sheet. Can I clarify whether there are further amendments to be circulated? I have been able to find some amendments by Senator Murray on behalf of the Democrats, plus the government's.
—It is not within the knowledge of the chair if there are further amendments to be circulated within the chamber. I am sorry, but this is an incomplete running sheet.

—I do not have any opposition amendments for starters. I know that there are other amendments from Senator Stott Despoja, and on the running sheet the opposition ones are coming up first. I am just wondering about this.
—We have opposition amendments up here.

speech.para: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Bolkus, by way of an interjection, has indicated that they have been circulated. It is sheet 1487 and the time and date at the bottom of that sheet of amendments is 10 August 1999 at 5.30 p.m.

—At the outset can I please table a supplementary explanatory memorandum and also address the proposal put by the opposition. I understand that it has been put forward with the best of reasons. However, I think it is best to stick with the standing orders and deal with the long title last. There will be a debate on the bill and there may or may not be amendments during the course of that debate and I think it is appropriate at the conclusion of the debate to then look back at the bill that you have and consider the long title. I think that is why we deal with the long title at the conclusion of the debate: so that senators know what we are dealing with. It is somewhat like putting the cart before the horse. Therefore, I would put to the chamber that the government is not minded to support that proposition.

—There are unique circumstances here and I do think, in relation to this particular bill, that the long title does inform the debate, as I have indicated. But I also would knowledge that, if we are to approach the question in a different way than might ordinarily be the case, then that requires all senators in the chamber to be comfortable with it. I appreciate that the Australian Democrats and the Australian Greens believe that this would be a sensible way of proceeding but I acknowledge that Senator Harradine has some concerns and that Senator Ellison, who is handling the bill for the government, is very lukewarm about the proposition.

speech.para: On that basis I do not intend to press the issue and I am sure that senators will have a mind to the substantive issue as we deal with it in the committee stage of debate. I do not want to delay the committee on this general question any longer. It is something certainly worth progressing but only worth progressing when all senators in the chamber and those who are representing different points of view are comfortable with a different approach on important legislation in a key committee stage debate.

talk.start.para: —Leave is not granted.

—Madam Chair, as a courtesy to the chair and as a courtesy to the chamber, I should advise you that amendments circulated in my name are those that are presented by me as an individual senator, not on behalf of the Democrats. The Democrats have been well aware of my personal position for well over two years. I think that, whilst there is quite a deal of sympathy for my position within the party room, nevertheless I should not misrepresent my views as reflecting those of the party room and I will be presenting those amendments individually. If the chair would accept that understanding, I would be grateful.

—I hope that when the completed running sheet comes out that is taken note of because I do have a whole bundle of amendments that are down as being moved by Senator Murray on behalf of the Democrats. They are on sheet 1472. I take it, Senator Murray, that those are the ones that you will be moving as an individual and not on behalf of the Democrats?
—Yes, Madam Chair. There are two sheets from me: one is 1472 and the other is 1492.
—The question is that the bill stand as printed. According to the running sheet, the first amendment is opposition amendment No. 1 on sheet 1487.
—I move:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (after line 25), at the end of section 59, add:

Until the Parliament otherwise provides, but subject to the Constitution, the constitutional conventions concerning the appropriate sources of advice for the Governor-General in respect of the exercise of the reserve powers applying immediately before the office of Governor-General ceased to exist shall apply in respect of the President.

By way of a general introduction, I indicate that the opposition is moving the amendments that we moved in the House of Representatives. The flavour and impact of those amendments were in essence to pick up the recommendations of the advisory report of the Joint Select Committee on the Republic Referendum. This is one of those areas where the committee did make some recommendations and I will turn to those in just a few moments. However, also at the outset can I say that we do not intend to embark upon a long, protracted debate. Others might do so in the chamber this morning but we do not intend to embark on a long, protracted debate in respect of these issues. For us the core issue is the question that is to be put to the public.

In respect of this, recommendations 8 and 9 of the report are essentially the source of motivation for the opposition to move this particular amendment. This amendment provides that, subject to the Constitution, the constitutional conventions concerning the appropriate sources of advice for the Governor-General in respect of the exercise of the reserve powers applying immediately before the office of Governor-General ceased to exist shall apply in respect of the President. In essence, this amendment seeks to do a bit of housekeeping to ensure that the sources of advice continue to be the same for the President as they would otherwise have been for the Governor-General.

talk.start.para: —Briefly, for the reasons outlined by Senator Bolkus, the Australian Democrats think this is a logical and appropriate amendment. We will be supporting the amendment before the chair.

—For the record, the government opposes this amendment. It does so on the basis that the recommendation by the joint committee concerned more the advice on the exercise of non-reserve powers while this is couched in terms of `in respect of the exercise of the reserve powers'. There is a difference there and the government believes that this, in effect, does not carry out the recommendation of the joint standing committee.

—I point the minister to recommendation No. 8 of the joint standing committee where, quite clearly, the committee is of the view that consideration be given to amending the bill to state that `the conventions which currently determine the appropriate source of advice should apply in respect of the President'. As I say, this is a housekeeping matter, but I do not think the minister should be under any misconception that the committee did not have a view in respect of the sources of advice. That is exactly the language we are seeking to apply through our amendment to the legislation.

speech.para: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bolkus's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I refer the committee to amendment (2) on sheet 1472. That amendment refers to page 3 of the bill, section 59, Executive power. The amendment says that `the exercise and extent of a reserve power shall not be subject to review by any court or tribunal'. The reserve powers of a President together with the conventions guiding their exercise are placed in the Constitution in the proposed section 59. By this fact, these powers could become justiciable. This could have the practical effect of dragging the High Court into a political controversy to review whether an act of a President was constitutional. This would be unprecedented in our constitutional history, and could cause delays and hinder the proper use of the reserve powers.

speech.para: While the crisis of 1975 was undeniably tumultuous, it was resolved in the political arena. The High Court was already stained, in my opinion, by the involvement of Barwick CJ in the controversy, but it would have incurred much more damage had the High Court been placed in the position of reviewing Governor-General Kerr's actions. In my opinion, the role of the High Court must be, so far as is possible, to be a separate independent arbiter on the proper construction of constitutional provisions. Involvement in political crises could seriously impair its capacity and authority to perform this function. It is my view that it is not a body well placed or equipped to perform that role. Having said that, it is imperative that the reserve powers of the Governor-General are carried over to the President, along with the conventions that guide their exercise. That is why I have just voted with the opposition on their amendment. I submit that the proposed section 59 paragraph 3 should contain the explicit direction that the reserve powers and conventions mentioned in the paragraph are not to be subject to review in any court. It is my belief and understanding that that is the present situation and I think it is desirable that it continue. I accordingly move amendment No. 2:
(2) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (after line 25), at the end of section 59, add:
The exercise and extent of a reserve power shall not be subject to review by any court or tribunal.

talk.start.para: —It is the opposition's view that the government has an amendment which covers this precise point of justiciability. It is that amendment that the opposition prefers to the amendment moved by Senator Murray. It is an amendment we find to be more in line with the advisory report of the Joint Select Committee on the Republic Referendum. When Senator Ellison moves it, we will be supporting the government's amendment.

—As a Democrat I do support Senator Murray's amendment in this circumstance. There is good argument proffered by people like Professor George Winterton that if it is the will of the parliament that the reserve powers not be justiciable then perhaps there should be some reference to that in the bill. That is my understanding of what my colleague seeks to do. We will be supporting him on that.

—Senator Murray was talking about 1975, and I was looking at this amendment which appears as if it is going to be accepted—at least the concept. That of course was not the problem in 1975. The problem there was—and Senator Murray mentioned it—about the Chief Justice, Sir Garfield Barwick. It was what he did before the dismissal that was of concern. It was the giving of advice to the Governor-General as Chief Justice that led to the concern and distress at that time. Listening to Senator Murray it seemed to me that this provision does not overcome the problem that led to the tumult at that time. I understand that what he is saying is that the decision of the Governor-General or the President to exercise a reserve power should not be subject to the High Court, but that is not the issue that was a problem in 1975; the issue in 1975 was the discussion between the Governor-General at that time and the Chief Justice about matters which, I would say, propriety should not have allowed.

—The government does not support Senator Murray's amendment. As pointed out by Senator Bolkus, we have an amendment, our amendment No. 5, which deals with this. Our amendment inserts a new clause 8A and deals with justiciability. It states:

speech.para: The enactment of the Constitution Alteration (Establishment of Republic) 1999 does not make justiciable the exercise by the President of a reserve power referred to in section 59 of this Constitution if the exercise by the Governor-General of that power was not justiciable.

That preserves the status quo. We believe it is in accordance with the recommendations of the joint committee. The status quo is the reserve powers, and the conventions which govern their exercise are high political matters which are not subject to review by a court. That view has been questioned from time to time. In the approach to this, the government has thought it best to follow the recommendation of the joint committee in leaving things as they are, but it still keeps faith with the convention model. It rules out any argument that any reserve powers or conventions are lost in the transition to a republic. It preserves the status quo whilst accommodating any change. For those reasons, the government will be opposing the amendment.
Amendment not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move Green amendments Nos 1 and 2:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (line 29), omit "may", substitute "must".
(2) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (line 31), after "citizen", insert "recommended by that committee".

These amendments take away the discretion of the Prime Minister to nominate any citizen and ensure that the Prime Minister must nominate one of those citizens whose name is put forward by the committee specifically established for that purpose. I cannot see much point in having a committee that puts forward a list of potential presidents to the Prime Minister for the Prime Minister then to select somebody entirely different.

There is, as we know, a lot of concern amongst the Australian electorate that there is not going to be, under the formula presented by this bill, opportunity for direct election of the President by the people of Australia. What came out of the Constitutional Convention is the alternative means of input for the selection of a President: any Australian can put forward the name of a person or persons who they believe would make a good President to a committee set up to vet those nominations, to narrow the field and to put forward a short list to the Prime Minister, who then makes a selection. If that is approved by the Leader of the Opposition, the vital steps have been made towards the selection of a new President.

Under this legislation, however, the Prime Minister can get around that. The Prime Minister can look at the short list which has come through that public nomination process and select somebody entirely different. On Channel 9 the night before last Prime Minister Howard pointed to this very shortcoming as another reason for people voting no at the coming referendum. This Greens amendment gets around the Prime Minister's ability to argue that that nomination process is a farce. It tightens it up. It ensures that the Prime Minister is limited to the list put forward by the Presidential Nominations Committee.

The committee will be aware that I have an amendment which I will move later to also make that nominations committee balanced in its representation of the Australian people. It will, amongst other things, mean that the Prime Minister, who nominates the committee, will have to take into account states and territories of origin of people going on the committee, sex, age, cultural diversity and the desirability of indigenous representation.

This is a minimal alternative to the direct election process. It is very important that we tighten this up, that we make that Presidential Nominations Committee a real representation of the Australian people, that we make its work valid and that we do not leave open to the cupidity of a future Prime Minister the ability to treat it with disdain and go outside the nominated list put forward and select somebody else. That has the potential of course for a Prime Minister to ensure that, in the future, he or she chooses a President who comes from their own political party or their own persuasion or who is seen as a safe bet rather than somebody who has come through the public nomination process.

They are very important amendments, simple as they may be. Amendment No. 1 substitutes the word `may' for `must'. It says that the Prime Minister must take a nominee from the list put forward by his or her own Presidential Nominations Committee. It is a very simple and important amendment. I recommend the amendments to the committee.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the two Green amendments before us for many of the reasons outlined by Senator Brown. We think it is quite an appropriate amendment to place an onus on the Prime Minister that he will act in accordance with the wishes and the recommendations of the nomination committee. The Australian Democrats appreciate that there are some already existing safeguards and provisions in the legislation which ensure that the Prime Minister has regard to the committee's recommendations, but we do not believe there are enough safeguards to ensure that the Prime Minister of the day does not simply ignore or override the will of that committee.

speech.para: The nomination process was a key, I believe, to the success of this particular model in the final stages of the Constitutional Convention last year. An important ingredient of that was allowing for public input into that nomination process and ensuring that the public input was appropriately diverse and reasonably representative. That is an issue that we discussed in the joint select committee process. I am glad to see that the second recommendation of that committee was accepted. It states:

. . . Nominations Committee Bill be amended to require the Prime Minister to, as far as practicable, have regard to the diversity of the Australian people when appointing community members of the Nominations Committee.

All these factors are very important. We should have some sense of certainty in relation to the Prime Minister's actions. The previous speaker referred to some rather glib comments by the Prime Minister in a Channel 9 interview a couple of nights ago that concerned me. There is a need to ensure diversity is taken into account and that the will of the people on that committee is not overruled and ignored. Certainly, this is one way of doing that and the Democrats support it.

talk.start.para: —I indicate at this stage that the opposition does not support these two amendments. We have concerns about the statements made by the Prime Minister the other night. Given anyone with bad faith—and he seems to be showing it at the moment in respect of this process and this legislation—you will, of course, have a number of issues raised that, at the end of the day, probably will not be the issues that they are because of the intervention of the Prime Minister in the debate the other night.

speech.para: In respect of these amendments, we say that there has to be some degree of flexibility. The word `must' is probably inappropriate when it comes to the necessity for an agreement between the Leader of the Opposition and the Prime Minister. You cannot force that sort of agreement. A degree of flexibility is important. In respect of the first part of the amendment—`must move for a President to be appointed'—we have a view that the reality is that that will happen once the system is set up, so there is no need to have the obligation that is implied in the word `must'. We do not agree with these two amendments and will be opposing them.

talk.start.para: —When considering this very important question, it is important for the parliament to ensure that, as far as possible, the will of the people is upheld. I make the observation that the committee established under this schedule is an appointed committee; it is not an elected committee. The Prime Minister of Australia is elected. The question is who is to be made responsible for the appointment of the President.

speech.para: Under this provision, the Prime Minister can put forward a name to the parliament, but the motion requires seconding by the Leader of the Opposition and affirming by a two-thirds majority. For the Prime Minister and, ipso facto, the Leader of the Opposition to be required to accept the person nominated by an unelected committee—he will normally do this, obviously—then it really places the ultimate decision in the hands of an unelected committee. I do not think that is in the interests of democracy.

If they make a mistake they will not have to bear any burden because they are, after all, only appointed. But, my goodness, if the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition make the mistake then they are politically accountable. They are elected and they are the ones who should bear the brunt if anything goes wrong. I offer those views on these amendments.

talk.start.para: —I would like Senator Brown to consider that if you put this in—and we were talking about the High Court before—this certainly does become judiciable because a challenge could be made on the basis that the Prime Minister did not take into account the matters set out here sufficiently or at all. I am not sure whether Senator Brown wants that. If you accept these matters, how do you deal with other matters, which I cannot conceive of now, that develop into issues and become relevant in the next 50 or 100 years? Why are we limiting it to issues which may seem anachronistic 100 years from now?

—In response to both issues, I come back to the issue of the people of Australia. I am not going to support a situation which is farcical whereby a committee is established to which the Australian people put in nominations and then the Prime Minister can gazump it, ignore it. In response to Senator Harradine, the Prime Minister is going to nominate this committee, hopefully with reference to the diversity of Australians. The Prime Minister is responsible for the committee. There is no getting away from that. If the committee does not give the right choices to the Prime Minister then it is on his or her head.

speech.para: We already have in this legislation the situation where that committee is appointed and the Prime Minister is responsible for it. If the Prime Minister makes a hash of establishing that committee then of course the people can judge that at the ballot-box. But this committee has been established as a means—it is a very vital component—of offsetting the disappointment many Australians are expressing that this legislation does not enable the direct election of a President, because so many Australians want to be able to vote for a President each time that vacancy occurs. What I am saying here is that the Constitutional Convention said, `Well, the best way we can assuage that wish by Australians under the system that has been devised is that there be a committee set up, that that committee be appointed by the Prime Minister but it then consider the nominations coming from Australians as to who should be President.' That is all. That is where the Australian people get their input.

The committee and the Labor Party here, along with Senator Harradine and the government, are saying, `Well, yes, we have the committee set up. The nominations all go in, but then the Prime Minister can ignore that.' We are just simply giving more power to the executive office, to the Prime Minister. I do not think that is what we are about in this place. I think those parties who are saying no to this amendment should think again. Maybe the Labor Party sees itself back in office at some future time and it wants its Prime Minister to have this power. Of course that is going to happen, but it is not giving the Australian people the dinkum opportunity, minimal as this process might be, to feed in their nomination for President and expect that nomination to be treated with the respect it deserves.

If the Prime Minister can get round that nomination process then you are devaluing it. Its value is limited as it is, and I think to devalue it further by opposing these two amendments is the wrong way to go. I certainly want a division on this, but it may be that I am not even going to get support for that. Let that be on the record.

talk.start.para: —I would like to deal with these amendments in two parts. The first substitutes `must' for `may'. One of the weaknesses of the bill and the proposals is that it is possible that there may exist an indeterminate period when an Acting President is in place. It is improper, in my view, for that situation not to be resolved. What the first change would do, without taking responsibility away from the Prime Minister to make the decision, which is the present intention of this bill, would be to require him to make that decision or require her to make that decision—and may it soon be a her as well—as a result of the committee meeting and making some recommendations to him. So I think the change from `may' to `must' is a useful improvement on the bill.

speech.para: However, I find the second amendment difficult to support because that just says `recommended by that committee' and, as we all know, this is at least a two-part process—it is probably a three-part process: firstly, the public are invited to provide nominations; secondly, the committee meets and comes to a conclusion; and, thirdly, the Prime Minister of the day is required to consult, as the bill says, with the Leader of the Opposition. As we will discuss later, I am of the opinion that consultation should be with the heads of political parties within the parliament. If at some day in the future the coalition dissolves back into two constituent parties, I think it would be utterly improper for the Leader of the National Party not to be consulted and I certainly think it is improper for the Leader of the Australian Democrats not to be consulted. So the stricture that it is confined to the decisions recommended by that committee is in contradiction to the bill's intent, to the model's intent, and is a restraint. Senator Brown, I indicate to you that I like recommendation 1 but I cannot support recommendation 2.

talk.start.para: —Senator Murray is indicating a difference of opinion on the two. Therefore, I seek leave to separate the questions so they can be looked at serially rather than together.
—You do not need leave to do that. We can do that from the chair, Senator Brown.

—I just want to draw the attention of the Senate to the third recommendation from the advisory report of the joint select committee. I think this picks up on the fact that while there may have been an awareness of a need for flexibility, for lack of a better word, in terms of how the Prime Minister responded to the nominations committee's recommendations, it also balances that with some form of accountability. The recommendation reads:

speech.para: . . . that the draft legislation be appropriately amended to provide that where the Prime Minister nominates as President a person other than a candidate mentioned in the short list from the Nominations Committee, the Prime Minister be required to table a statement in Parliament giving his or her reasons for deciding that such exceptional circumstances existed for failing to comply with the Nomination Committee's recommendations.
I ask the government for its official response to that third recommendation contained in the advisory report.

talk.start.para: —I ask the minister in his response to give an indication to the committee of his view as to Senator Cooney's statement that it is judiciable. Isn't it a fact that the Prime Minister cannot simply ignore the recommendation that has been made by the nomination committee? Indeed, the provision of the legislation that we are considering says:

speech.para: After considering the report of a committee established and operating as the Parliament provides to invite and consider nominations for appointment as President, the Prime Minister may, in a joint sitting of members . . .

If the Prime Minister simply ignored the recommendations of the committee, is it a fact that that matter could be tested in the courts? Could the minister indicate whether that would be the situation?

talk.start.para: —While the minister is considering that, I will say that of course that is the situation. Either way, it is going to be available to some citizen to take any matter in this legislation to the courts, but I submit that that is not the point. The point I am trying to make is that we should make the input of the Australian people valid so that the Prime Minister has not only to take notice of what they have said but to select a presidential nominee, whose name has originally been put forward by the Australian people, from the process which is established here. We should not make this selection committee process and the input of the Australian people a farce, if the Prime Minister seeks to go outside it. Of course, any Prime Minister who comes up with their own presidential nominee outside the list put forward by the committee is going to say, `I considered the committee's list, but I've got somebody who is better.'

speech.para: If we adopt my amendment, which says that the Prime Minister must select somebody from the short list put forward by the committee, any Prime Minister who has a nominee whom he or she wants to see as President has the simple mechanism of recommending their nominee to this committee. If they are a good nominee, they will be on the short list. It is not cutting the Prime Minister's wishes out. It is a process. I am ensuring here that the Australian electorate does not get cut out in this process.

talk.start.para: —I should point out that Senator Brown's interpretation of `must' and my interpretation of it differ. I think that is important to the debate, because this `must' means that the Prime Minister must make a decision. This `must' does not say that that decision must be more than informed by the committee. They are two processes: to receive the committee's recommendation and to consult with the Leader of the Opposition. If ever this matter were dealt with, I would expect that the committee's recommendation would weigh very heavily on the Prime Minister. My reading of that clause on a strict interpretation—and there are some lawyers in the gathering in the chamber—is that it simply means that he must make a decision, not that he must make that decision in favour of the list given to him by the committee.

—Senator Murray, I recommend that you accept both of the amendments. It then means that the Prime Minister must make a decision and that the decision must be from the list put forward by the committee, which is adjudicating on nominations coming from the Australian people.

—There are a number of matters. The government opposes these amendments Nos 1 and 2 by the Greens. I will deal with each in turn. Firstly, the changing of the word `may' to `must' does imply a sanction. In fact, we would agree with Senator Cooney's assertion that this heightens the aspect of justiciability. It is something which Senator Harradine was concerned with. It imposes a more cast-iron obligation on the Prime Minister and, of course, that is the intention that the Greens have here. But the more you do that, the more you open it up to judicial review, and that is something which the government thinks is problematic.

speech.para: In any event, there is a clear expectation that the President will be appointed at the end of an incumbent's term. This has operated for many years in this country with the way that governors-general are appointed by the Prime Minister. The practice has been observed, and the government believes it will continue to be observed because there will be political pressures to do so. The convention provided for an Acting President in circumstances where there might be a gap between appointments. I put to the Senate that the convention was not of a mind to say that there should be an automatic requirement—the insertion of a `must', if you like—in relation to the Prime Minister's actions. It saw that the current system was sufficient and that there would be sufficient pressure to appoint a successor to the incumbent. Therefore, the government is of a view that it would be inappropriate to require the Prime Minister in the circumstances mentioned.

The government's proposal allows for the opportunity for the Prime Minister to engage with the Leader of the Opposition to nominate a presidential candidate. You do not know what might transpire in the affairs of human beings. You might have someone who is on the way to being nominated who passes away or for some other reason is ineligible, and it is then back to the drawing board. Meanwhile, you would have this sanction of `must' hanging over the Prime Minister. It is the view of the government that, in the circumstances, there are adequate safeguards that carry on the current practice and that are not contrary to the convention model.

As for the second amendment, the government is saying that the proposal is in accordance with the convention recommendations. The Prime Minister is technically under no obligation to nominate someone from the short list. However, again, there would be immense political pressure to do so. The requirement of a sanction again opens this up to judicial review and again does not accommodate something which might transpire, such as someone becoming ineligible to be moved forward. For that reason, the government is of the view that this should not be changed. The convention said that, having taken into account the report of the committee, the Prime Minister would put forward a single nomination. The convention did not say that it must be from the short list, although it was intended that there be political pressure that it be from the short list—and, in most cases, it would invariably be from the short list. Nonetheless the convention proceeded on the basis that the Prime Minister would not be bound to move a name which was from the short list, much for the reasons I have pointed out.
There is another aspect mentioned by Senator Stott Despoja in relation to recommendation 3 of the joint committee which provided that:

. . . where the Prime Minister nominates as President a person other than a candidate mentioned in the short list . . . the Prime Minister be required to table a statement in Parliament giving his or her reasons for deciding that such exceptional circumstances existed for failing to comply with the Nomination Committee's recommendations.

The government's response is in the document I tabled earlier. In substance, that recommendation is supported. Under section 60 of the Constitution, the Prime Minister is technically under no obligation to limit his or her nomination to a person from the short list provided by a nominations committee in its report. The Constitutional Convention's resolution is expressed in terms that the Prime Minister is to `take into account' the committee's report. It is clear that debate at the convention proceeded on the basis that the Prime Minister should not be under obligation to appoint a person identified by the nominations committee, although it was rightly recognised that the political realities would impose pressures to do so. I outlined that earlier.

It is possible to identify circumstances in which it may not be appropriate to nominate a person recommended by a nominations committee. An example is where agreement could not be reached with the Leader of the Opposition on any of the committee's short list. In any nominations procedure, the Prime Minister has to obtain the backing of the Leader of the Opposition. Another example is where an outstanding candidate excluded from the committee's consideration because of an apparent unavailability subsequently agreed to be considered when approached by the Prime Minister and by the Leader of the Opposition. It may well be that the nominations committee looked at a pool of candidates but excluded an outstanding candidate who was thought at the time to be unavailable, that that then changed and that the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition both then thought this person should be approached. That would rule out an allowance for that to be accommodated.

The government would not accept any proposal to amend proposed section 60 of the Constitution to fetter the Prime Minister's constitutional discretion. However, the government supports amendments of the nominations committee bill to provide explicitly for a Prime Minister who moves a name that is not on the nominations committee short list to inform the parliament of reasons for the alternative nomination. The government would undertake to move an amendment in those terms accordingly when or if the need arose to consider the nominations committee bill. The government is saying that it would agree to the Prime Minister having to table reasons as to the choice of this alternative candidate. It would not be a situation where the Prime Minister would have to give reasons for deciding that such exceptional circumstances existed for failing to comply with the nominations committee recommendations—a subtle difference but nonetheless one which we believe is more preferable. It would perhaps avoid the odium of comparison.

In the situation recommended by the joint committee, you would invite a situation where the Prime Minister might say, `These weren't as good as the one I am looking at,' or, `There was some problem with these candidates.' We are saying that, if the Prime Minister does choose an outsider—to term it that way—the Prime Minister would give reasons saying why that person was such an outstanding candidate. For those reasons, we believe there should be a subtle difference in the way we support recommendation 3 of the joint committee.

talk.start.para: —I thank the minister, but I am totally unconvinced. We can always come up with a list of `what ifs'. What if the Prime Minister died in office? What if the Deputy Prime Minister went down in a plane crash at the same time? We can always come up with `what ifs'. We are dealing with the practicalities of the situation and the passage of political power. I am moving here power to the people, not more power to the Prime Minister. We are in an age where the executive is accreting more and more power to itself. I do not want to be part of that process. It may suit the big parties to be, but I think the model we have here is not the favoured model of the Australian people. Australians want to be part of the process of nominating a President. They do not want a Prime Minister, even if recently elected by them, to be able to gazump that process or to get around it. We should be making that clear here. I can see I do not have the numbers, but I reiterate that these amendments are about power to the people.
—The question is that Greens amendment No. 1 be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —The question is that Greens amendment No. 2 be agreed to.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —We now move to opposition amendment No. 2.
—The opposition is not pursuing this amendment; we withdraw it.
—I move amendment No. 3 on sheet 1472, as revised:

speech.para: (3) Schedule 1, item 3, page 4 (lines 1 and 2), omit "seconded by the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives", substitute "supported by the leader of each political party with at least 5 members in the Parliament".

This amendment has been revised—for those who are looking for major changes—to make sure it notes that I am speaking on behalf of myself and not on behalf of all the Democrats. In moving this motion, I will give a brief resume of my reasons. The proposed section 60 provides that the Leader of the Opposition must second the nomination of the President. That makes the bold assumption that a single formal Leader of the Opposition will continue to exist in Australian federal politics in the long term. Given that our Constitution needs to remain workable during the course of the 21st century and given the knowledge we all have that constitutions are extremely difficult to change, it is desirable that such assumptions be soundly based.

It is clear from our parliamentary history that the House of Representatives two-party system of today—and even so it is not two-party because, as we know, the coalition is already composed of two—has not always prevailed. The Liberal Party, for example, was formed in 1944 out of the remnants of the United Australia Party and 13 other anti-Labor organisations. A survey of the OECD nations reveals that, out of 29 countries, 23 have multiparty oppositions as opposed to formal single-party oppositions. Given the increasing fluidity of contemporary politics, it would be naive to simply assume that the existing Australian party system will not undergo significant changes over the coming century. Therefore, proposed constitutional change should not be so short-sighted as to be founded on a view that the two-party system is here to stay.

I submit that a provision should be added that the candidate nominated by the Prime Minister have the formal support of the leaders of all recognised federal parliamentary political parties prior to the candidate's name being put to the joint house vote. I know that the constitutional committee has recommended that the words `if any' be added following `the Leader of the Opposition'. But that to me is a poor additional change. It helps, but the real emphasis of the Constitutional Convention model was that some kind of consensual agreement should be reached within the parliament—and I agree with that. I agree that it is desirable and helpful for the Leader of the Opposition to agree with the Prime Minister that the appropriate presidential nomination is the right one for the country; I think that is right. But, if you are going to take `consensus' in its appropriate meaning, you should consult with the leaders of all recognised political parties—with the Leader of the National Party, with the Leader of the Australian Democrats and with the leader of any other political party that is recognised in the parliament.

The answer may be, `But the nomination has to be approved by a joint sitting anyway,' but that approval process occurs after the consultation. My point simply is to try to ensure that the consultation takes place first. If it is the intention of the Constitutional Convention and if it is the intention of the government and the opposition in supporting the bill that they support a consensual model, why limit it to a notional Leader of the Opposition who might not exist at some future time and not involve a consensual approach to leaders of all political parties that are recognised at the time?

As an aside, I was interested to see in the formation of the new Israeli government, for instance, the government being composed of something like 11 or 13 parties and the opposition, as such, being composed of another 11 or 13 parties.
Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You come from a long history of factional brawling, Senator Bolkus. We both understand the tensions that can emerge from time to time in any political party. I make the point that none of us can foresee the future; we do not know whether this will turn back into a two-party system, remain as it is at present or become much more multiparty than it is at present. Personally, as you know, I incline towards the latter, but I cannot foresee the future. I am simply suggesting that, if this constitutional change is to be embedded and passed by the people, it should cater for future eventualities better than it does at present and better than the recommendation put by the committee that was reviewing this matter.

—The opposition opposes Senator Murray's amendment. We see it as not meriting our support for a number of reasons. First of all, it is not within the recommendations of the Constitutional Convention, nor within the ambit of the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Republic Referendum. Let us understand that those two processes were about reflecting a long process of consultation—the involvement of the public—in the development of a proposal which could be presented to the people and which would have a chance of success in any referendum of the Australian people.

speech.para: Senator Murray, it seems to me that you have been spending too much time with the Prime Minister, because on this and many other amendments today you seem to want to develop as many snags in the proposal going to the public as necessary to ensure that it does not survive the referendum process. Your laughter probably indicates that I may have touched on your motivation here. We see this as a gridlock amendment, basically. We understand why you would put it up. We recognise that any good debate in public would ensure that the public was made aware of the fact that what you are proposing here is a gridlock amendment.

In terms of the gridlock amendment, our view is that it would be an enormous process to try to get agreement however many parties were in this place at the appropriate time. At the moment we cannot even see agreement within the Democrats on a particular course or direction. If the constitutional process had to wait for the Australian Democrats to come to a consensus about who would or would not be appropriate, it could become quite unbearable.

Senator Murray, the Israeli model is one that you have proposed to us. As I said to you as an aside, maybe that is the model you want to see for the Australian Democrats, but I do not think we should imperil the constitutional process through the whims of parties which may in fact be minor parties of the day. For us there are sufficient pressures, triggers and constitutional requirements in the model to ensure a consensual approach is taken. The model brings together the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition and it brings together the parliament. It requires a two-thirds majority of the parliament. The whole spirit and constitutional structure is one which demands and necessitates a degree of consultation and agreement. We think that spirit will ensure that not only would the Leader of the Opposition be consulted but also the names evolved by the Presidential Nominations Committee would involve an input from every other party and individual in the community and the parliament. We see your amendment as a gridlock amendment and we do not support it.

talk.start.para: —Senator Bolkus is in fine form today, but I should acknowledge that this is an amendment around which there is no division or tension. In fact, the Australian Democrats as a whole strongly support the amendment proposed by Senator Murray for the reasons he has so eloquently outlined. Referring to the Constitutional Convention, Senator Bolkus and others would be aware of my attempts, as the Australian Democrat federal delegate at that convention, to incorporate wherever possible maximum consultation with Australian people and politicians and to ensure that all political parties had some formal role in the processes. I was successful with one set of amendments to ensure that the leaders of political parties with more than five representatives in parliament were involved in the Presidential Nominations Committee process. I am glad to see that that amendment was successful. Other attempts, however, to ensure a formal role for leaders of parties other than the two main parties were not successful, but that does not mean that the Democrats have shied away from those attempts to improve this legislation.

speech.para: We do not think it is particularly difficult to imagine future circumstances where the non-government benches seat a number of opposition parties. We are moving already to an increasing multiparty system in our own parliament, and Senator Murray has referred to what happens in parliaments and governments around the world. This particular amendment not only allows for any future flexibility we might need in our Constitution, but also ensures that the proposal of a candidate by a two-thirds joint sitting of the parliament is a consultative process and, therefore, we think, perhaps a more successful one. The Constitutional Convention sought to ensure that the candidate proposed to the parliament involved a consultative process through many of the ways we have outlined—the nominations process, public input, et cetera. We believe that consultative mechanism is important.

I am not sure whether the opposition withdrew its amendment which reflected the recommendation of the advisory committee report because they thought that it may be incorporated by the government or that someone else might move it, but I am a bit surprised by that decision. There has been a number of references by government and opposition members today to the recommendations contained in that report, and I think that was a report that grappled with some of these issues—whether there would be an identifiable Leader of the Opposition in the future, and what impact that might have on the success of the nomination and the appointment process; that is, if there were not an ascertainable Leader of the Opposition would the seconding and appointment processes be in some way compromised or undermined.

Not only with those thoughts in mind—that is, would there be an identifiable Leader of the Opposition—but also I think to ensure that there was that adequate and increased level of consultation, the recommendation that arises out of the committee's report, recommendation No. 4, reads that the republic bill be amended by inserting the words `if any' in proposed section 60 following the words `Leader of the Opposition'. So I think there was a multiparty recognition of the need to include those words.

I speak on behalf of the Democrats strongly in favour of Senator Murray's amendment. We will be supporting it. We do not see it as an attempt to introduce some kind of gridlock to this process but in fact to expand the process in an inclusive and a consultative way.

talk.start.para: —I think there are two issues here. There is the nomination and then there is the debate. It is quite clear that, if the nomination has to be affirmed by two-thirds of the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, everybody is going to have a say. It is almost going to be like a confirmation hearing, I suppose, which does change things from the way it is done now and goes closer to the American system, where they have confirmation hearings for judges and other officials.

speech.para: It seems to me that, if you are going to have the leader of a party of five or more, then why shouldn't you have people like Senator Brown and Senator Harradine coming in at the initial stage. I would have thought that the idea of having a Prime Minister's nomination seconded by the Leader of the Opposition is a practical one because the government and the opposition are going to have the pull on the floor of the chamber in which these matters are discussed and it is sensible to at least have a fighting position to put to the House of Representatives and the Senate when these matters are being discussed. I am not sure why you should then have everybody who is leader of a party of five or more in that process. It would in effect transfer that process from the debate in the chamber, where everybody can have a go, to a college of electors, as it were, where it would be the leadership of the parties rather than the membership of the parties who are going to have the say.

What is really being proposed, I think, is that the President be elected by the leaders of the various parties rather than by two-thirds of the House of Representatives and the Senate. As it presently reads, people like Senator Brown and Senator Harradine have a big say and can make their voices heard when the debate is taking place as to who should be President. But under the system proposed by Senator Murray, for whom I have got the highest respect, you would have a college of the leaders of the parties electing the President, and I do not think that is what is intended.

talk.start.para: —I will briefly respond to that. Senator Cooney, as I read the legislation, at present it is a college of two. In other words, the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition will fix up the President, go back to their respective caucuses and they have secured the two-thirds. That is with the existing numbers in both houses of parliament at present. All we are suggesting is that it should be widened. Remember that this is a consultation process. The actual voting, of course, is by individuals in both the House of Representatives and the Senate and would include Independents and political parties without recognised status. The reason we have not included consultation with everybody not representing a political party is simply that if that becomes widespread, in other words if you had 30 or 40 Independents, it could be difficult to manage, and the parliament at present does run on the recognised political party model.

speech.para: I must make it clear that, as you know, I oppose the appointment model, but this is a mechanism which I believe widens the consultation and widens the prospect of the appointed President being less of the potential creature, if you want to express it that way, of one political party. It is not automatic that it would happen that way. I think the Labor Party in its term of office made some extremely useful appointments in the Governor-General role, and we all in this chamber have immense admiration, I think—I certainly have not heard anyone ever express otherwise—for the present Governor-General. So I am not imputing a bad motive automatically based on past practice, but I am indicating that for the future the proposal I put forward adds more to the appointment model than it has at present. Of course, I should qualify all my remarks throughout by making it clear that I oppose the appointment model and I am a supporter of direct election, as you know.

talk.start.para: —I understand what you are saying, Senator Murray, and understand that you are in favour of the model that directly elects the President. This document, like the original Constitution, is very much a compromise document, as any constitution bill would be. What has got to be taken into account is the practicalities of the situation, together with the manifestations of the aspirations and ideas that we have.

speech.para: It seems to me that the compromise reached in this particular document, where for practical reasons the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition take into account whose name should be put forward before the parliament, is one that strikes people as understandable and reasonable. I am not saying that yours is not but why limit it to five? Why not say everybody should be part of that preliminary process? As you say, there has to be some sort of sense in all of this. All that has been said is that the best sense, in light of the sort of compromise that can be reached, is that the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition make the nomination and then it is up to everybody, including the smaller parties and those who do not belong to a party, to debate whether they are going to accept that nomination.

talk.start.para: —In response to Senator Cooney—and I acknowledge that he raises the important issue of compromise and what is workable—if one were to ask the question of what really is wrong with the bill as it currently stands, the Democrats would believe that it entrenches the two-party system. It entrenches the notion that only two leaders count in our political system. That may be a theory to which the two old parties in this chamber subscribe but increasingly many Australians have shown in their voting intentions—and in research it is also evident—that Australians are looking forward to the idea that there may be more smaller parties or even Independents; a multiplicity of views in a multiparty system. But this entrenches that, so from a philosophical and a political point of view that is something to which I and my colleagues object.

speech.para: But also, as Senator Murray has pointed out, who knows what the future holds? It is obviously presumptuous of me to suggest that it does necessarily involve multiparty systems but a lot of the evidence that we are getting—from this country, from the voters, from our constituents and from looking at parliaments across the world—is that indeed that is what the future holds. I think we should be seeking, in updating and modernising our Constitution in this way, not to entrench old systems that entrench two power bases but to look towards more inclusive and consultative mechanisms.

I do not see this amendment as not feasible or as completely unworkable. I think it is an important caveat that it involves the leaders of parties; that is, people with party status, and you can even include the National Party under this notion. So we are not talking about so many groups as to make it unworkable but about enough groups, and the leaders of those groups, to ensure that the nomination is supported—not seconded, because I note that Senator Murray has used the terminology `as supported'—and to do so in a way that ensures that this nomination is acknowledged and welcomed by all. Perhaps that will set a fine precedent and standard for the way in which the community and other groups respond to this Australian head of state.

So I would like to see this amendment as part of the process of modernising our Consti tution that we are embarking upon to reflect our changing times including our changing political times—changing times, I hope, that are politically for the better. The Democrats would not be a alone in that. I think we would have strong community support for the notion that this is not about two leaders signing off on a particular nomination; it is about involving other political parties and the representatives that the community has put in the institutions of power here. I commend this amendment. I hope that perhaps the old parties will reconsider their perspective.

talk.start.para: —The government is unable to support this amendment or the others. It would point to the recommendations of the Constitutional Convention and also of the joint committee on this matter. The convention envisaged a proposed procedure where the committee would invite and consider nominations from the public and give a report on the nominations to the Prime Minister. Following consideration of that report by the nominations committee, the Prime Minister would then move, in a joint sitting of the Commonwealth parliament, that a named Australian citizen be chosen as President. The Leader of the Opposition would second the Prime Minister's motion. A two-thirds majority of the members of the Commonwealth parliament would then have to approve the Prime Minister's motion.

speech.para: We have there a situation where you have community consultation accommodated by the nominations committee, which will be made up of people drawn from the community and members of parliament. Its nomination then goes to the Prime Minister, who seeks the backing of the Leader of the Opposition. Once that is obtained, it goes forth to the joint sitting of both houses of parliament and there it requires a two-thirds majority. So there are a number of hurdles that have to be negotiated during this process and every one of those affords the people of Australia transparency and accountability in the choice of a President for this nation.

The government believes that if we, at that one point in the sequence, introduced a further hurdle whereby that motion had to be supported by another leader of a political party as described by Senator Murray's amendment, you would have the opening up of a possible gridlock situation, as Senator Bolkus has mentioned. I know that is not what Senator Murray intends. He intends that this amendment accommodate more consultation and that it provide a broader base for the proposal of the motion. But the government believes that the proposal of the motion—being the Prime Minister, seconded by the Leader of the Opposition—is sufficient.

Perhaps most importantly, this is what the Constitutional Convention envisaged. It is really in accordance with the recommendations made by the joint committee. The joint committee did not say that there should be this aspect, with a further person being sought to support the motion. Senator Cooney's point is a good one because the members of these minor parties and the Independents would be participating in that crucial point of considering the motion. Their views would then be taken on board. For those reasons, the government cannot support this amendment.

talk.start.para: —I do support this amendment. We are into a multiparty century. The two-party system is going. Australians, like people elsewhere around the world in all democracies, are looking for greater opportunities for choice. This amendment simply says that a party that has the public backing to have five members of parliament should have a say. Of course they should.

speech.para: I note the comment that this would leave me and Senator Harradine out at the moment, but the line has to be drawn somewhere. I look forward to the time when there are plenty of Greens in here to take part in the process. But right around the world, wherever you look, there are multiparty governments and oppositions these days. In fact, the majority of democracies return multiparty governments.

talk.start.para: —Like the National Party and the Liberals.

—Yes, so if the Nationals are interested in fostering the empowerment of their voters, they should support the amendment put forward by the Democrats. It is as simple as that. If they are locked into what the predominant Liberal Party wants, then they will not be supporting it. It is a matter of whether or not they have freedom of choice within that coalition. I think they will be letting down their members if they do not support Senator Murray's amendment.

speech.para: I hope that the One Nation senator comes in here and supports it too if that party thinks it is going to have a number of people in this place further down the line. I note that the senator was not here to support my earlier amendment that the nominations committee be empowered in a way that the Prime Minister could not get around. It is difficult, it is early in the piece, but we are discussing very important democratic processes here. As Senator Murray quite rightly pointed out, this is a once-only opportunity. We are talking about the process for a referendum to set constitutional matters which are going to be very difficult to alter further down the line.

Senator Murray's argument that we have moved into a multiparty period in Australia is backed by the fact that you only have to look at the last election to see that 25 per cent plus of people are voting away from the old parties. Should those people not have a double say in this process? That is, the leaders should get together, put forward a nomination and then two-thirds of the parliament should be required to vote for it further down the line. It is easy to bring up a term like `gridlock', but what about a gridlock between Labor and Liberal? We are not resiling from that potential. In fact, the very reason for the Leader of the Opposition being empowered here is to ensure that there is a smooth consensus process in the nomination of a President. If another party in this place had five members, that party should be involved in that. That makes good democratic sense and I support the amendment.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Murray's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —I would like to advise the Senate of an alteration I need to make to amendment (4) on sheet 1472 revised in view of the last decision of the Senate. The amendment now says:

speech.para: If the Prime Minister's motion is not supported by the leader of each political party with at least 5 members in the Parliament, or is not affirmed . . .

After the words `If the Prime Minister's motion is not supported by the leader', the words `of the Opposition' are to be inserted and the words `each political party with at least 5 members in the Parliament' are to be omitted.

talk.start.para: —Senator Murray, would you care to just clarify that? Would it be better to have `not seconded by the leader of each political party'? That is a repetition of the words above: `seconded by the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives'.

—Sorry, Madam Chair; I may not have made myself clear. I intend to take out the words from `each' through to `Parliament'. So out would come `each political party with at least 5 members in the Parliament' to substitute the words `the opposition'. So I will read it to ensure that the Senate is clear on my intention. The amendment will now read:

speech.para: If the Prime Minister's motion is not supported by the Leader of the Opposition or is not affirmed by a two-thirds majority of the total number of the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, the Prime Minister must, within 6 weeks of the joint sitting of the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, move in another joint sitting that another named Australian citizen be chosen as the President.

I would like to make some brief remarks. I hope Senator Brown took note that I used the word `must' in line with my previous support for his intentions in that area. Section 60 does not provide for a scenario where the Prime Minister's nominee is not approved by parliament. We all know that in politics you can never be certain of what is to come. If there is one thing you learn in politics it is that that is a fact. Section 60 should provide that, where the Prime Minister's motion to appoint an individual is unsuccessful, a different candidate must be put forward at another sitting within a specified period. In this amendment I have suggested six weeks. The Senate may choose to vary that period. But the point is that you cannot have a situation which is left without resolution, in my view.

You also have to pay attention to the fact that it may be in the interests of the Prime Minister of the day to have such a situation. There may be a time when a Prime Minister might see leaving the office vacant as helpful to his or her political aims, or they might choose to leave the office vacant for a period in order to pressure the parliament to approve a nomination which the parliament or the Leader of the Opposition plainly do not want to support. All this amendment is trying to do is ensure that there cannot be such an event.

I do not believe from my understanding and reading of the Constitutional Convention's proposals or my understanding and reading of the committee report or indeed of anything I have heard from the supporters of the appointment model that what I am proposing goes against either the spirit or the intention of what they were trying to pursue. In a sense, this is a technical amendment, but I also think it covers an area where there might be genuine political dangers. I think it is wise to guard against them. Accordingly, with those brief remarks, I move:
(4) Schedule 1, item 3, page 4 (after line 5), insert:

If the Prime Minister's motion is not supported by the leader of the opposition, or is not affirmed by a two-thirds majority of the total number of the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, the Prime Minister must, within 6 weeks of the joint sitting of the members of the Senate and the House of Representatives, move in another joint sitting that another named Australian citizen be chosen as the President.
