If Mohammed cannot come to the mountain, it is a case of taking the mountain to Mohammed—or to the school children concerned. I was very impressed last week at the way the teachers brought students into the district education office in Port Hedland, which is where I was, and set up a parliament, appointing a prime minister, a speaker, a leader of the opposition and ministers. The children became totally absorbed in role-playing the respective jobs that they were given.

In addition, last week the Parliamentary Education Office went to Hedland College where it provided a mock parliament to the English as a second language class at the college. The nationalities represented in that class included Malay women, Thai women, Venezuelan women and Vietnamese women. As it happened, they were all women. Given the restrictions on their understanding of English, the Parliamentary Education Office managed to get these people to participate in a mock parliament and to do so enthusiastically. They all left with a good appreciation of how our parliamentary system works.

The other unique and important thing that the PEO did last week during its visit to the Pilbara was to visit an Aboriginal community. It went to the Yandeyarra community, which is about 120 miles out of Port Hedland. That was the first time the Parliamentary Education Office had been to a school at an Aboriginal community anywhere in Australia. Yandeyarra is a very successful community. It is a model almost of what an Aboriginal community could be, with a very nice village, a good school and a medical centre which is well set up. They have a station of about one million acres in the old coinage. As was said by one of the officers from the Parliamentary Education Office, it was like having a vast parkland for these people to live in and enjoy. They also run a very successful cattle station and mining operation.

Again, I was very impressed by the way Geoff Clarke and his staff—Camilla Blunden and Ali Garnet—simply walked into this Aboriginal community and talked to the kids about something which interested them, and that was the idea that people were stealing snakes, birds and other animals from their country and what should they do about it. They all decided that it was wrong and there should be a law to prevent people stealing their snakes and birds. So a bill was set up to be passed in the mock parliament. These little Aboriginal children very enthusiastically joined in the role-playing.

I commend the Parliamentary Education Office for devising a concept which these Aboriginal children could relate to. In the other schools they had a proposal, for example, that school hours be extended, which of course most children opposed. This would not have worked so well at Yandeyarra because they do not have regular school hours: people seem to come and go as they choose. But the idea of a law where animals should not be stolen appealed very much to these Aboriginal children. I would certainly like to thank the people at the Yandeyarra school: the principal, Mark Rawlins; the teachers—Lisa Carthy and Tina McVicar—who helped set up that mock parliament; as well as the Aboriginal educational assistants, Marlene Walker and Jenny Walker, who were very helpful.

One of the objectives of the Parliamentary Education Office is to improve young Australians' understanding of our Constitution and our system of government. They are doing this through the program, Discovering Democracy. The Discovering Democracy program was established because a Constitutional Commission report in 1988 found that only 50 per cent of our population understood that we had a written constitution. A 1994 study found that 73 per cent, no less, of people over the age of 15 had a total lack of knowledge of the role of the Governor-General in our Constitution. The Parliamentary Education Office is part of the program to ensure that Australians have a better under standing of our Constitution and our form of government.

One of the findings of the Turnbull committee, which looked into the question of the republic about five or six years ago, was that most Australians assumed that our Constitution was similar to the American Constitution, and were stunned to find that we did not have things like a bill of rights and so on. The need to educate Australians about our political system, our Constitution and our form of government is one of the great unmet needs in this society of ours. We should be paying more attention to educating children about our political system at a school level to overcome this huge deficiency in knowledge about how our political system works.

It is interesting that in other countries, like the United States, children have a very good understanding of how their political system works. They have a very good understanding of the history of the American Revolution, and they also have a very highly developed sense of national pride—the American flag is everywhere one goes in the United States—and that is an example that we could well emulate in Australia.

As I said, I would like to place on record my appreciation of the fine work that the Parliamentary Education Office is doing to promote knowledge of our political system and the workings of our parliament. I would like to once again congratulate Geoff Clark and his team for the particularly good work that they are doing with their outreach program and for taking that program to many parts of Australia when students are not able to come to Canberra to participate.

talk.start.para: —Tibet is a nation of six million people on the roof of the world in Central Asia, but it is not a free nation. It is the largest occupied nation, and the largest colony on the face of the planet at this end of the 20th century. I made a private visit to Tibet over the winter break, and I want to make some preliminary comments about that visit and forthcoming events to do with Tibet. I can inform you that I will be submitting a full report on that trip to the Senate in the next few weeks.

speech.para: The media background information, which is available to members of the Australia Tibet Council, reports that next week the third annual round of the Australia-China bilateral human rights dialogue takes place in Beijing. These private talks between bureaucrats will take place only three weeks before President Jiang Zemin of China visits Australia. China has already indicated that President Jiang is likely to announce a $15 million natural gas deal with Australia during the visit, partly because of the support that Australia has given to China in its recent confrontation with Taiwan. This is only one of several bilateral trade deals under negotiation in the lead-up to President Jiang's arrival. In this climate, the third round of the dialogue in Beijing seems certain to be at least as ineffectual as the previous meetings when it comes to confronting the serious human rights abuses taking place in Tibet and, indeed, throughout China.

The Australia Tibet Council's position is that the dialogue should be suspended pending a parliamentary review into its effectiveness. I cannot but wholeheartedly agree. The position of government in Australia regarding the military repression in Tibet is totally out of keeping with the feelings, as I have gauged them, of the people of Australia. We need to redress that. A starting point for that is increased debate in this national parliament—something that I intend to foster.

When I went to Tibet with other people at the start of August, we first went to the western city of Xining and from there bussed to Dulan, a town on the main road from Beijing to Lhasa. In doing so, we went onto the northern part of the central Tibetan plateau. This is where the World Bank intends to invest some $US40 million, backing a Chinese scheme for the resettlement of 58,000 Chinese people from the Xining area, 400 kilometres to the east, onto the plateau. This will be done by the diversion of a river, the establishment of 126 villages and the creation of a massive network of irrigation canals, which directly obstructs the passage of the nomadic Mongol and Tibetan herdspeople bringing their herds down off the mountains for winter onto the plains and back again in summer.

There are a number of delegations: a media delegation last week, and the Australia China Bilateral Human Rights Dialogue delegation is being hosted to the area by the Chinese government. I think all these visits are going to fail on two counts. Firstly, none of the delegations will be taken to the wetlands—an important breeding site for the black-neck crane, which is emblematic of China and Tibet—because they are 200 kilometres out in the desert. The wetlands are going to be deprived of water by this scheme. I doubt any of the delegations are going to see the herdspeople whose lives are going to be dramatically changed by this influx of 58,000 people from elsewhere, because they are with their flocks up in the mountains at the moment. In two- or three-day visits it is simply not possible to contact those people.

There will be a lot of debate about this issue in the coming months. At least the World Bank has put its commitment on hold until there is a further study. The World Bank ought to require a minimum one-year environmental impact study and cultural and economic impact studies of that massive area to be affected on the northern Tibetan plateau before it goes ahead with that project. As well, the World Bank ought to be insisting that 58,000 poor Tibetans are put into that region—not add to the immigration problem by which China is quite deliberately moving millions of Chinese citizens into the Tibetan plateau so that the Tibetan people will be, if they are not already, a minority in their own land.

I went to Lhasa and was immediately impressed by the militarisation of that place. I cannot understand how other parliamentarians visiting the area could have come to a different conclusion. On landing at the airport in Lhasa, I saw nine fighter jets at one end of the airport, a military camp at the back and soldiers with guns placed on all four perimeters of the airport. On the way to and from the airport in Lhasa, there were passing convoys of military vehicles—some of them full of troops.

The first thing you note on the way into Lhasa is the destroyed buildings on a hillside. When you ask what happened there, you are told that that was part of the massive destruction of Tibetan culture which took place under Mao Tse Tung's government, the Cultural Revolution and the immediate predecessors of the current government—many of whom were in Beijing fostering this destruction of the Tibetan people's culture back in the sixties and seventies. In Lhasa itself there are military vehicles, but these are not gun carrying and rocket carrying vehicles, which people might look for; they are military vehicles—trucks and four-wheel drives—carrying military personnel. There are military personnel and police on the street like I have seen nowhere else in China, let alone in the free countries of the world.

It is very easy for MPs, as well as other people, to visit a place like Tibet and, not seeing people being knocked down in the streets or hearing gunshots, to think everything is toward. You have to have contact with the Tibetan people to realise the repression that is going on there. It is only safe to do that out of the vigilant watch of the military personnel and the predominantly Chinese population in the business centre of Tibet. Most of the businesses these days are owned by the Chinese. The ownership predominance has transferred from the Tibetan people to the Chinese immigrants, who have become the extension, the watching eyes, of the government.

One thing that impressed me enormously was the readiness of young Tibetans—they are the ones who tend to speak some English and, given the opportunity and reassurance that they are speaking to a friend of Tibet, will come up and start conversing with a Westerner—to express their utter wish that the Dalai Lama return to Tibet and that Tibet be given its freedom. I think that visitors who do not expose themselves to or do not find themselves in that situation have missed a connection with the Tibetan people. It is okay to be taken around by Chinese guides, to stay in Chinese hotels, to be given the Chinese tour patter, but this is very little different, in my book, from parliamentary delegations who went to the USSR in the thirties, forties or the fifties and came back reporting that all was going well, that there was advancement of the people, that the economy was getting better, that production was better and that education standards were better—that all these parameters were better—while not daring to push the authorities and look behind the brutality of that regime in those times. We now all know better.

I do not believe we can shut our eyes to what is happening in Tibet. When you put your head down at night in the comfortable modern hotels—Chinese-owned hotels—in Tibet, you know that in the prisons a few blocks up the road there are monks and nuns by their hundreds who have dared to stand up for their beliefs, who are not just in prison but who are in lengthy months of solitary confinement—very often in fouled cells—and who are subject to torture, including electrified cattle prods and, unfortunately, on occasions, rape. There are harrowing accounts of extended periods of torture. I believe that no MP worth their salt should ever leave this country again and go to Tibet without speaking first to ex-prisoners from those gaols who are now part of the exiled Tibetan community here in Australia. I believe it is a failure to properly understand the plight of the Tibetans for MPs, business people and visitors at large who want to understand what is going on in Tibet to not do the study at home first.

The Australia Tibet Council has now issued a list of recommended procedures for people going to Tibet which I thoroughly endorse as a minimum for anybody who does not want to be foxed by the propaganda and the tightly controlled guiding system that the Chinese government invokes in this occupied country to our north.

Of course China wants to keep control of Tibet. It is to them `a treasure trove of forests, mineral resources and hydro-electric potential', and of course they keep vilifying the Dalai Lama and misrepresenting the position of the Tibetan government in exile. Do we have to accept that as a parameter in our negotiations with the Chinese government? The Chinese government, remember, denies all other political parties the right to exist in China, let alone the Tibetan people their right to freedom of expression, or at least a minimal right to vote for self-determination as espoused by the International Commission of Jurists.

Next week, this next round of bilateral dialogue will take place with Australians, including Mr Peter Nugent from the House of Representatives, going to Beijing. I believe these dialogue talks should be, at minimum, suspended and, better still, abandoned, because they are a charade which allows the Chinese and Australian governments to put the issue of Tibet on the shelf. We go to those talks under terms dictated by China but foreign to our open, free and democratic system. Why should these talks be held in secret? Why should there be no definitive reporting? Why is it the government has such a minimal cost allocation and such a minimal delegation system for these talks? Why are non-government organisations or, indeed, representatives of groups like the Tibetan people not taken into account, let alone taken along on these visits?
I am mindful that President Jiang Zemin himself will be in this country at the start of next month. I understand there will be a parliamentarians dinner on 8 September to honour him.

talk.start.para: —I hope you behave yourself at that.

—Senator Boswell's interjection is a reference to me calling President Clinton's attention to the issue of Tibet when he was here two years ago. I am forever glad I did. If behaviour means our having a steely resignation to the repression of the Tibetan people, going silent and acquiescing, acceding to the dictates of the Chinese authorities—remember these are not elected Chinese authorities; this is, in effect, a dictatorship—then I am not going to have a part of that. Of course I will behave, but I will be impelled in any circumstance where I have the opportunity to speak with Chinese officialdom—and they turned down that opportunity when I was in Beijing as if they were frightened to talk about this issue—of putting to them the plight of the Tibetan people.

speech.para: I have a very strong feeling that is what most Australians would want all parliamentarians to be doing. I will be referring this matter through a full report to the parliament in the next few weeks. I urge the government to rethink about being a part of this charade next week in Beijing.

talk.start.para: —This is the sixth in a series of addresses that I have given in this chamber on the matter of illicit drug taking and the ongoing drug crisis in Australia. I am very proud to remind honourable senators that the Howard government is the first Commonwealth government to have taken a national or whole of government approach to Australia's drug problem. Until the launch of the Tough on Drugs national strategy on 18 March this year and our resolute commitment of $290 million in grants under the Tough on Drugs program, Australia previously had a hotchpotch approach to this problem.

speech.para: What I am not proud of, and what I want to underscore today, is that, no matter how much money we spend on the problem of drugs within our community, unless we have a major and decisive shift in the attitude about illicit drug use in our community, all our efforts are going to be constantly put at risk and with potential lethal ramifications that most people simply are not aware of.
Let me explain what I am getting at. I will start by quoting something that Bob Carr, the Labor Premier of New South Wales, said in the opening of the Drug Summit on 17 May 1999. The Premier said:
Drug use is part of our society, part of our culture, part of the Australian way of life.

This is a statement that should have everyone really worried. It should set off alarm bells everywhere. I really do not think that the Premier would accept that drugs are now so inexorably and irredeemably part of Australian way of life that all we can do effectively is just fiddle at the margins. That would be a nonsense if it were the case.

But that is exactly what is likely to happen if people continue to make fine speeches and write long academic texts that differentiate between hard drugs and soft drugs and when they distinguish between the use of pharmaceutical drugs and what they term recreational drugs. Think about the implications of such terminology for the type of attitude that we are fostering in our community, particularly amongst our young people.

What is a soft drug anyway? What does it mean to say that a drug is soft and what is a recreational drug? My Oxford English Dictionary tells me that, if something is soft, it is `gentle, smooth and calm, and produces an agreeable or pleasant sensation characterised by ease and quiet enjoyment. It involves little or no exertion or effort'. My dictionary also tells me that a recreation is `an agreeable pastime, amusement or occupation which refreshes and enlivens the human spirit and body'.

What sort of attitude are we fostering in our young people when we say that marijuana, hashish and other such types of drugs, which have such insidiously powerful effects, are gentle and smooth, and freshen and enliven the human body, mind and spirit? Although we may be able to understand how a layman like the Labor Premier in New South Wales could inadvisably refer to drug taking as part of our Australian way of life, I do not think we should show the same restraint when someone like Professor David Penington, a former Vice Chancellor and Professor of Medicine at the University of Melbourne, agitates for the decriminalisation of marijuana use because it is a soft or recreational drug.

I listened to what he had to say when I attended the New South Wales drug summit in May this year, and I really could not believe my ears. Here was a leading scientist and medical practitioner who seemed to be ignoring the growing evidence of the insidious effects of marijuana because it did not suit his personal point of view. By taking this stand, he does policy makers, the community and individuals who might be tempted by so-called soft drugs a great disservice. Like so many others who trivialise the enormous risk taken by people when they get onto the slippery slope of drug taking, Professor Penington seems to choose to ignore the reality that marijuana can cause a vast array of medical as well as psychiatric problems, including, in some cases, death. Most people do not usually associate marijuana usage with death, but Dr John Anderson, a consultant psychophysiologist with the Brain and Behaviour Centre in Westmead, set out just such a terminal scenario in a major policy conference last weekend.

I will reconstruct Dr Anderson's argument and will do so point by point, because it deserves our very serious consideration. Point 1: the level of THC, which is the active ingredient in marijuana, has been steadily increasing over the last few years, due partly to ongoing developments in hydroponics and the use of hormones to induce growth in plants. The level of THC in marijuana has gone from being just four per cent in the 1970s to 10 per cent, then 15 per cent and up to 30 per cent in the 1980s. Even without all the fancy equipment and growth hormones, we now have in our midst a type of marijuana called `New Guinea gold' from the highlands of Papua New Guinea which has an amazing THC level of 42 per cent.

Point 2: the higher the level of THC present in marijuana, the more profound the effect on the brain of the user. It does not just make the drug user of the 1990s a lot higher than the Woodstock hippie of the late 1960s and early 1970s; it actually retards his or her brain function. It is not just that it slows down the brain's actual growth, which continues in human beings up to the age of 27, but it does this in an exponentially more thorough way than it has ever done before.

Point 3: the solubility of marijuana, which is referred to in medical literature as its lipophyllic nature, has two extremely dangerous characteristics, which function to prevent rapid metabolism and excretion from the body. As a result, THC stays in the human system for about 30 days through cumulative use, and can now be stored for longer and longer durations.

Point 4: in conjunction with other well-documented effects of marijuana, like a reduced flow of oxygen to the brain, what happens after a period of constantly storing so much THC in the body is that people invariably start to exhibit classic symptoms of depression, schizophrenia and other drug related psychoses. They invariably go to their local GP who, more often than not, puts them onto an antidepressant type of drug.

Point 5: we now come more directly to the scenario which was outlined for me by Dr Anderson and for which there is growing medical and scientific correlating evidence. Parents who find their children dead might think they had been a bit depressed for a time and might have encouraged them to go to the family doctor. Their children would have seemed happy enough once on prescribed antidepressants, but young people often do not tell the doctor that they are smoking marijuana. It is the interaction of marijuana and antidepressant drugs like prozac which can cause a deadly effect in some young people. What can result from that situation is accidental and inadvertent death.

It will be shown up that the person died of an overdose of antidepressants, and the parents would anguish about this because they would be wondering where they went wrong. Why did their child join the growing suicide statistics? But there is increasing evidence that a lot of these deaths could be caused by the interaction of these two substances and, if the level of THC in marijuana had not gone from four per cent up to as high as 42 per cent through today's usage, this sort of death might be avoided.
Let me say here that it is unlikely that many parents and doctors would have come to this realisation, as Dr Anderson explains:
Most doctors are not aware of the interaction of prescribed medications and illicit drugs. Currently there is no reference source for them to use.

Medical evidence of this correlation is now only just starting to come to light. Only last year, in 1998, there was a report in the Australian Journal of Psychiatry of someone who died because of that patient being on a lethal combination of antidepressants and marijuana. Dr Anderson has told me of similar reports from overseas.

Point 6: my final point is the appalling connection between marijuana—which people claim to be a so-called soft or recreational drug that the Oxford English Dictionary tells us is gentle, smooth and refreshing to the system—the classic medical symptoms which are usually alleviated by antidepressant types of medication and the tragically bizarre phenomenon of an increasing number of Australians, mostly young people, apparently committing suicide by taking an overdose of their medication.

There is nothing approaching the concept of recreation or fun in anything I have told you today—quite the opposite. There is nothing soft about the statistics on marijuana. The hard fact, as stated in the documentation that Dr Anderson has sent me, is that:
Australia has the dubious honour of the world's highest suicide rate aged 14 to 55 per capita and also the same dubious honour of being the largest consumers of cannabis in the world.

While I conclude my contribution to this debate on a very depressing note, we must face the darkness of this issue before we can walk towards the light. We have to do this so that we can rescue those who are most vulnerable in our community, and we need to do this before they settle into the increasingly deadly option of so-called soft and recreational drugs like marijuana.

talk.start.para: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Ethiopia led by the Speaker of the House of Federation of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, the Hon. Woi-Zero Almaz. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators I propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

para.inline: The Hon. Woi-Zero Almaz was thereupon seated accordingly.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Trade. In view of the APEC meeting in September and the upcoming World Trade Organisation meeting in November-December, will the new protectionist Minister for Trade, Mr Vaile, be offering to brief other APEC and WTO member nations on the virtues of slowing down the pace of tariff reform, as he believes Australia should do? Does the government believe that Minister Vaile will get international support for this view? How many of Australia's export industries are in support of Mr Vaile's preferred policy position?

—I think that Senator Cook might have misunderstood Mr Vaile's position in this matter. Mr Vaile obviously reflects the government's position—and that is that ongoing trade liberalisation is in Australia's interest. We are burdened by trade barriers in our markets, and the more they can be reduced, the better off Australia is going to be. I even recall that being a position advocated by Senator Cook when he was the minister in this area, so he will be pleased to hear my answer in that regard. At the forthcoming trade discussions Australia will be taking the position that further liberalisation should be encouraged and supported, and we will be endeavouring to persuade others to that position.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that assurance. It is different from what Mr Vaile told Laurie Oakes in his Sunday interview. In view of that answer, is it still the government's policy to pursue the goal of `aggressive bilateralism' at the expense of multilateralism as outlined in the coalition's 1998 election policy? Does the government believe that aggressive bilateralism is preferable to trade multilateralism, and will this be Australia's position as it enters the APEC and WTO trade round discussions? How is aggressive bilateralism of more advantage to Australia's exporters than the opening of many markets under a multilateral approach?

—Regrettably, again I fear that Senator Cook has misread or misunderstood the government policy. Government policy is to take all opportunities to reduce trade barriers and open markets—whether it can be achieved on a bilateral basis or on a multilateral basis. What the coalition did say was that the previous government, of which Senator Cook was a member, erred in putting too much emphasis upon multilateralism at the expense of taking full opportunity under bilateral occasions as they present. In its bilaterals this government has vigorously sought—and I think Senator Cook need only refer to the record of Mr Fischer in this regard—to open markets at each and every opportunity as it has presented. Through the WTO and other venues, it has similarly sought to persuade a broadscale opening of markets. So it just requires a correct interpretation of the policy. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Will the minister inform the Senate about the price reductions which have occurred in the implementation of the new tax system? Will he also inform the Senate of reactions to the reduction of wholesale sales tax on 29 July?

—Thank you, Senator Gibson, for that question. Senator, you have had a long role in the history of tax reform. In fact, you headed up a consultative committee, as you will be aware, that assisted in the development of this very successful tax package, which we went to the election on, which we were elected on and which we passed in this chamber after a very long debate.

answer.para: Some of the benefits of the new tax system are already flowing through to Australian consumers. Firstly, may I remind the Senate of the abolition of Labor's complex wholesale sales tax, which was originally formulated in the 1930s and of which Senator Sherry and the Labor Party remain among the few supporters. The abolition of the wholesale sales tax will complement the massive income tax cuts that the government is delivering to taxpayers. Of course, many families will receive tax cuts of up to $40 to $50 a week when the system becomes fully operative. These tax cuts will mean that 80 per cent of Australian taxpayers will have a marginal rate of 30c in the dollar or less. And it is to be remembered that many goods will not rise in price but many will fall.

Senators will be aware that during the debate there was the attempt to constantly portray that there would be massive price rises. That was quite untrue. As Senator Gibson reminded us, on 29 July, 21 days after royal assent was given to the new tax system bills, the first tax cuts began and most goods that were previously taxed at 32 per cent wholesale sales tax fell to being taxed at 22 per cent wholesale sales tax. As we know, those goods will fall to 10 per cent GST next year. These goods include clocks, TVs, cameras, watches, radios, stereo players, et cetera. These tax cuts represent the first stages of the change to the tax system in this country—changes and tax cuts that the Labor Party opposed.

Let me inform the Senate of some of the comments from retailers regarding the wholesale sales tax reductions on 29 July. I have before me the Queensland Times from Ipswich. The headline is `Town races to grab tax bargain'. The article says:
Ipswich BT Edwards store manager, Mr Brian McNamara, said $200 came off items such as TVs, stereos, videos, hi-fis and walkmans.
He went on to say:
I think it's a tremendous thing. It's great for the general public in terms of prices being more reasonable. It will boost business.
And it is not just on the east coast. Retravision's chairman said:
The floodgates are well and truly opened, and we aren't complaining. We've already done 50 per cent more than what we would normally do on a good Thursday.

That is what the Retravision manager said in relation to the tax cuts we were able to deliver in wholesale sales tax. The headline in the Adelaide Advertiser of 29 July sums up the mood for retailers and indeed for consumers—`Day one for GST shopping bargains'. If there is a supplementary question, I might continue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister have any other comments to make about the reduction in wholesale sales tax to inform the Senate of?

—Thank you, Senator. Indeed I do. Let me inform the Senate of how the first stage of the government's tax reform has affected some of the prices of various goods. I am advised that a medium range TV set would go down by up to $42, a video player down by some $24, a higher end stereo down by up to $126 and a higher end camera down by up to $70. It is worth noting that Labor opposed these tax cuts every inch of the way. In their debate Labor opposed these cuts. If we had left Labor's tax system in place, these major cuts in these goods would not have occurred. That is one of the reasons why the new tax reform system brought in by this government will be welcomed by the Australian people.

—My question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Does the minister endorse the comments of the trade minister, Mr Vaile, who has stated that Australia was entitled to a pause on the further removal of trade barriers? How is this consistent with his own decision to commence the process of removing the remaining industrial tariffs in the automotive and TCF industries? Is it government policy, as stated by the Minister for Trade, to wait for other countries to catch up before continuing with the removal of tariff barriers?

—The feeble opposition is trying desperately to find some small chink of light that they might pursue in relation to government policy on tariffs. The government has a very consistent policy on this, one not indistinct from the previous government's. We applaud the fact that one of the very few things the previous government did honourably and sensibly was to embark on a program of significant tariff reductions, and we are continuing with that program.

answer.para: I was pleased to announce at the end of the last session that we have instigated a complete review of our general tariffs. That is because we do believe in trade liberalisation, just as the previous government did. Every member of this government supports the cause of trade liberalisation and supports the review of general tariffs which I have announced. That is not an announcement that the general tariffs are to be removed; it is a statement consistent with our APEC obligations to review our general tariffs. In particular, we are focusing on nuisance tariffs, those tariffs which do not protect any Australian industry and which are the least defensible of tariffs and ones that I personally hope we are in a position to remove as soon as we possibly can.

We specifically said in that statement that we have put in place special arrangements for the automobile industry and the TCF industries. The tariff position with them is clear and known. I also made clear in that statement I made that in any review of general tariffs by this government we will be very closely watching the performance of our trading partners with respect to their own tariff position.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I welcome that answer but, in view of that answer and the announcement made on the Sunday program in a Laurie Oakes interview by the then trade minister elect, Mr Mark Vaile, that he believes that Australia should pause their tariffs until other nations catch up, who is speaking for the government, Minister—you or Mr Vaile? Who is telling the truth—you or Mr Vaile?
—Senator, you should direct your question through the Chair.

—Madam President, you will understand that of course the government was extremely upset with the decision by the United States government about lamb. The interview given by Mr Vaile was of course in that context. It is not government policy to pause our tariff reductions. However, consistent with Mr Vaile's sentiments, it is government policy that in reviewing our tariffs we take full account and cognisance of the performance of our trading partners with respect to their own barriers to trade, including tariffs.

—My question is to Senator Ian Macdonald, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. Will the minister inform the Senate of details of progress with the coalition's initiative to provide rural transaction centres in rural Australia?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator McGauran has an interest in these matters, representing rural and regional Australia as he does. I am very pleased to be able to advise Senator McGauran and other senators who are interested, which obviously does not include many on the Labor side because very few of them know what it is like outside the capital cities, that on 20 July—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There are too many senators shouting on my left.

—On 20 July the government was able to announce that the first of its rural transaction centre allocations had been made. Seven communities were funded for the establishment of the first of these rural transaction centres. They included: Cabonne Council in Eugowra, Gresford Community Group, Urana Shire Council, Aramac Shire Council, Dirranbandi Progress Association, St Marys Association for Community Development in Tasmania and the Welshpool and District Advisory Group in Victoria.

answer.para: Those seven communities are the first cabs off the rank, so to speak. They will get federal government money to set up these rural transaction centres which will, for the first time in many years, provide these small communities with basic banking access, postal, telecommunications, Medicare Ezyclaim, fax and phone facilities and video conferencing.

In addition to the seven who were funded outright, another 15 communities were given money to provide business plans so that they can make applications to provide rural transaction centres. The groups successful in those business plan applications cover many areas in Australia from the Jabiru Town Council right through to the Greenvale Progress Association near Townsville—which is where I come from—a group in Nanango, the Furneaux Enterprise Group on Flinders Island, Murrindindi Shire Council and the Bremer Bay Community Resource Centre, just to name a few.

We expect that the first of the rural transaction centres will be open within the next couple of months. We are very keen to get from local communities their ideas of what they want. That is what the whole scheme is about. They tell us the services they need, they propose the solutions and we then fund them for the capital costs and for the first period of their operation. This program was funded from the social bonus from the sale of the next 16 per cent of Telstra.

I had an uplifting experience during the so-called break. I visited a number of communities in remote, rural and regional Australia. I drove from my home in Ayr some 3,000 kilometres down through western Queensland, calling in on small country towns and understanding their problems. I was delighted to be able to go into the town of Aramac, which had received funding for a rural transaction centre. The joy in that community was tremendous to experience.

Since the Labor Party got rid of all the banks in rural and regional Australia and since services left regional Australia during the Keating and Hawke Labor governments, they have been without these facilities. To experience that pleasure and joy was very uplifting. In Aramac the funding is going into a licensed post office. The postal licensee was able to show me exactly where the money is going and demonstrate the services that will be provided.

I was pleased to be able to get out into regional Australia. I understand the shadow minister, Ms Kernot, was also visiting regional Australia. She flew into Rockhampton—a major provincial city—with her leader, Mr Beazley, and flew out again. That was her visit to rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —That is not right.

—I urge her and Senator Mackay to get out to these smaller communities and then they will understand the benefits of the government's initiatives in providing services for rural and regional Australia. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Hill in his capacity as Minister for the Environment and Heritage and Minister representing the Prime Minister. How can the minister claim that the process for determining grants under the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program was thorough, fair and consistent with the requirements of the Auditor-General when we now know that the minister and Senator Alston completely ignored this process in relation to 16 of the 60 successful projects? Why did ministers ignore departmental assessments in relation to these projects? Why has the government consistently resisted opposition attempts to get details of these 16 projects? What is the government trying to hide?

—I am surprised to receive this question because the issue had been debated at length in the estimate committee hearings. As Senator Faulkner is well aware, the process was that guidelines were published and were followed by ministers. In this instance, two ministers were to make the decision. As I recall, some 700-odd applications looking for funding of about $1 billion were received. Seventy million dollars was made available in this program.

answer.para: In addition to the published guidelines, ministers received advice from both officials and the Centenary of Federation Council. The advice of both bodies was taken into account in making the decisions. Ministers made their decisions and endorsed some 60 projects. The reasons for the decisions were given as well. The structure was set up pursuant to the previous advice that had been given by the Auditor-General. We believe that in form and in implementation it properly met the Auditor-General's requirements.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the minister seems so satisfied with the processes used to design this ultimate in pork-barrelling exercises, will he undertake to provide details of the 16 shonky projects? Would the minister have any objection to the Auditor-General being invited to conduct an audit of the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects Program?
—I would expect that the Auditor-General will do so. That is the task of the Auditor-General. That is no surprise.
—Why? Are you expecting an audit of that program, are you?
—Well, the Auditor-General chooses what he thinks is desirable.
—I asked you whether you invited him.

—No, you did not ask me whether I had invited him; you asked me whether I had any objection and I said that I would expect the Auditor-General to do his task. But there are a couple of falsehoods. This is the old Senator Faulkner technique: we recall it with the Baillieus—defame a dead person and then refuse to apologise to the relatives. The point is that 60 projects were approved. They are all good quality projects. They are all public. The 60 projects are public.
—Why don't you identify them?
—Order! There is far too much shouting.
—No-one has suggested that there is one inappropriate project.
—Name them.
—Senator Faulkner, it is your supplementary question.
—They are on the public record. All projects were eligible for choice by the ministers. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. I refer the minister to Minister Fahey's appointment of a probity adviser to inquire into the operations of CS First Boston following cancellation of their operating licence in Japan. I remind the minister that CS First Boston are the lead managers of the Telstra 2 share float. Will that inquiry also look into the role of CS First Boston in the first Telstra float, particularly the scandalous undervaluation of Telstra shares which cost taxpayers $5 billion in unrealised proceeds? Will it ask why CS First Boston advised the government to price shares at $3.30 when major stockbroking houses like JB Were and HSBC James Capel were advising their clients that Telstra shares were worth $4?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Here we go again. This is the crowd that do not even believe in privatisations, let alone want to take account of the way in which the real world marketplace operates.
—Don't upset her. You are not supposed to abuse them any more. They are on your side now. You have broken the rules now.
—It is all right. I told you we would not declare your low impact as silly, but I could reconsider.
—Senator Schacht, that is a most inappropriate interjection and I ask you to abide by the standing orders.

—Quite right. Senator Allison does not even pretend to understand how the marketplace operates, let alone understand that there is always a great element of uncertainty in terms of the forward movement of share prices which are obviously significantly affected by other factors quite often beyond the control of individual companies, let alone local markets. In other words, international factors, particularly in the US, can have a very significant impact upon the ultimate share price and its trajectory. To suggest that somehow because the share price of Telstra rose as investors recognised that it had great long-term potential represents some sort of scandalous undervaluation is a preposterous proposition that can only ever be trotted out in hindsight.

answer.para: In other words, if the share price had gone down, we would not for a moment have Senator Allison saying, `How could they possibly have come up with that figure?' Senator Allison must be aware of the numbers that were put on the total market cap of Telstra by the other side. Over a period of three or four years it ranged from $15 billion to $20 billion. When we said $20 billion we were laughed out of town. We are now up in the stratosphere compared to those earlier predictions. Those numbers are ones that were put forward in good faith by those responsible. We have no reason at all to regard the assessments made at the time as deserving of any probity inquiry.

The fact is that the concerns that Mr Fahey has addressed were ones that involved him approaching Mr Andrew Rogers before the Japanese Financial Supervisory Agency handed down its sanctions against CS First Boston on 2 August, and the chief executive of investment banking at CSFB Australia, Mr John Wylie, has made it plain on the public record that the issues examined by Japan's Financial Supervisory Agency had no impact on the Australian operations of the company, were not related to share trading and equity capital and there is no suggestion that these issues, which are peculiar to the Japanese financial market, apply anywhere outside of Japan. So in other words, it is perfectly proper for Mr Fahey, out of an abundance of caution, to have a look at what it was that led to that action being taken by the Japanese authorities. But that in no way of itself reflects upon the process that was followed in the course of T1. The government has no reason at all to go down the path that you are suggesting.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. However, he talks about the benefit of hindsight but this government had foresight. It had the advice of major stockbroking firms—it had the advice of the Australian Democrats—that these shares were worth more than $4 each. Again, I ask: how is it that the float advisers got this so terribly wrong? How is it that within weeks those Telstra shares were worth $4 and how is it that CS First Boston was again contracted to help run the second float? Will they now be removed and what action will the government take to recover the $5 billion lost on the first Telstra float because of poor advice?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I suppose this gets a good run in the Democrat newsletters because it plays to the prejudices of those who have not a clue about how privatisations operate in the real world. I seem to recall that about two weeks before Telstra 1 actually went to market there were some significant events that caused certain people to say that we should postpone the float, that we should not really go ahead at all. Were those people fundamentally wrong? You weren't one of them, I take it. You sat on your hands just hoping that the share price would dive, I suppose, so you were very keen for us to go ahead into those stormy waters. Of course what happened was that people recognised the underlying strength of the share and the management behind the company. That is a judgment that people will continue to have to exercise. I do not pass any judgment on its current valuation or its prospects for the future. I simply say that you appoint experts to give you that advice and we did just that. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Federal Cultural and Heritage Projects Program

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Can the minister shed any light on the 16 shonky federation cultural and heritage projects which he and his colleague Senator Hill selected for funding, notwithstanding departmental assessments that they did not make the grade? I ask Minister Alston: what were the 16 projects? Why were they chosen? Who recommended them? And why is the government refusing to provide any information about them?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —You really know you have run out of steam when you have to recycle this little issue that Senator Faulkner has been desperately trying to get up now for months and months. How long is it since the last election? It must be coming up to 10 months, and yet here we are still trying to get it off the ground. This issue was trawled over exhaustively in the estimates process. Of course, Senator Faulkner got a letter some weeks ago. He had to wait until Mike Seccombe got back from holidays before he could find someone who would actually give it a run.

answer.para: To really capitalise on this issue and make sure he really hit the spot, what did he do? Did he get out there, call a doorstop and talk to all of the major media players? No, he went on Graham Richardson's program this morning. Were they feeding one another! Mr Richardson said, `These two senators ignored independent advice, and they gave funding to what they now admit were 16 projects, even though the projects did not meet the minimum criteria.' Talk about a strict exchange of prejudices!

Richardson knows, as do you, that we were the recipients of two sets of advice from the National Council for the Centenary of Federation and a task force comprising joint officials from Senator Hill's department and mine. We made the ultimate decision about that. We took their advice, they gave us a list, we took that into account and we looked at all the projects. Of course, that does not stop you getting out there and saying, `I think they are probably dodgy projects.' I noticed you said so for the first time. I suppose you think you have to go a bit further to try to beat it up. Now, of course, he does not think; he knows. He comes into question time today and says, `These are shonky projects.' Let me just ask you: the 16 must be included amongst the 60 that we approved. Is that right? The logic of that is that, somewhere in amongst those 60 projects, all of which are on the public record, you are saying that at least 16 of them are shonky. Does that include the restoration of the Great Synagogue Tower in Sydney? Does it include the restoration of one of the most important historic ships, the Polly Woodside in Melbourne?

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I have a point of order.

interjection.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right will let me hear this point of order.
—Let the minister come clean and tell us what the 16 shonky projects are. The question is directed to him, and he ought to answer it.
—There is no point of order.
—I am delighted to answer it, because they were not shonky. It is very simple.
—What are they?
—Order! Senator Faulkner, stop shouting like that. Interjections of the kind that are going on are disorderly.

—They are quite simply projects that were selected by us from all those projects that were regarded as eligible. In other words, these were not ruled out because they did not meet minimum criteria. Look at that stuff that Seccombe trotted out this morning. I hope you were not responsible for the series of mistakes that he made. Talk about getting it fundamentally wrong—to say that they did not meet minimum criteria when they did, to say that we overturned an independent assessment process when we did not and to go on and say that we are in breach of the caretaker conventions when we were not. Are you responsible for this, or is Seccombe? Make up your mind. I can understand where you are coming from. You even went so far as to suggest that this was worse than the case of Ros Kelly.

answer.para: Let me just remind the Senate why Ros Kelly is relevant to this whole debate. This was the case of the missing coupes. There were four that were non-existent. Senator Faulkner went to cabinet indicating that all of those were of high conservation value, when it turned out that four of them did not exist at all. What did Laurie Oakes say? He said that Senator Faulkner had made a mess of things comprehensively, had intended to make himself a hero of the environment movement, that disillusion was setting in in caucus with Senator Faulkner's performance and that, rather than wanting to be Graham Richardson, he emerges from this episode more like Ros Kelly! There you go. It says it all. We know how to make decisions properly. You clearly did not.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask again for the minister to name the 16 projects. Isn't it true, Minister, that you received a departmental submission on 14 August 1998 where the departments, yours and Senator Hill's, presented to you a list of 114 projects which ranked 15 and above out of a total of 24 points? You and Senator Hill now admit that you approved 16 projects.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Faulkner is again ignoring your repeated urgings to him to address the question through the Chair rather than talking directly to Senator Alston. I know it is very difficult for Senator Faulkner to understand these things, but could you remind him again of what the standing orders say?
—Senator, you have had an opportunity to ask your supplementary question. You ought not to keep interjecting while the minister answers.
—I thought you had finished that time. Have you got more?
—What were the projects, and why were they chosen?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —They were chosen because we judged that they were deserving on the criteria that were adopted. The fundamental mistake that you make is that you somehow think that we were obliged to accept the advice offered. We never were. Anyone who looks at this understands that. I think you even got a glimmer of an understanding of this in estimates. Your trouble is that you have slipped back. When they had the tactics meeting, poor old Mr Beazley, who was on a very big slide, said, `What on earth can we run with this week?' Senator Faulkner said, `Maybe it's about time we dredged up that Federation Fund project again.' After all, you remember that they are not too good on policy. This is the bloke who got dumped as shadow minister for social security. He is now shadow minister for politics. Lord knows what he will do if they ever get to government, because there will not be a portfolio with that responsibility. You know as well as we do that we made the decisions. We took into account the advice that was offered. It was very valuable advice, but we were not going to simply slavishly follow what the department did in terms of cut-off points. You would; we would not. (Time expired)

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan led by the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives, His Excellency Mr Mefleh Al-Rhimi. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the chamber and trust that your visit to this country will be informative and enjoyable.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Would the minister advise the Senate of the current status of Australia's efforts to get Christopher Skase to answer the criminal charges against him in an Australian court?

—I thank Senator Payne for her question. As all senators know, Mr Skase has been the subject of serious criminal charges—company and bankruptcy charges—under Australian law since 1991. A number of warrants have been issued by Australian courts for his arrest, and those warrants remain active. The Australian government is committed to bringing him back to Australia to face these charges. Given the failure of the previous government's attempts to extradite Mr Skase from Spain in 1994, we know our best shot at bringing Mr Skase back to Australia is if he leaves Spain for one reason or another.

answer.para: I would have hoped that this is an issue on which all Australians agree. We could all pull together on this. At least in this instance, we could all be batting on the same team. We could hope that everyone at home wants to bring him home. After all, life is a confidence game. You would not want to think anyone in Australia would be giving confidence to the Skase team. However, on 20 July 1999, the Majorca Daily Bulletin quoted Mr Kerr—the opposition spokesman on these matters—as saying a number of things. Firstly, they quoted him as saying that `the only way Skase will finally be forced back to Australia is if new charges are laid'; secondly, that we, the Australian taxpayers, are wasting our money at the moment; and, thirdly, that `Skase will continue to run rings around the Australian authorities'.

If you want to give comfort to people who are overseas who think they can evade authorities, get yourself quoted overseas as saying that the Australian government is wasting its money and that the other side is a bit smarter than the Australian government. It is almost breathtaking, because these comments come from the man who was justice minister at the time the extradition proceedings failed. He was in government at the time. Now we can see why the then Attorney-General would not let him anywhere near the Skase matter: he would have messed it up even more than the Labor government messed it up at the time. For the people who gave Mr Skase a brand spanking new passport and who failed in the extradition proceedings to be now quoted in Spanish newspapers as saying that Mr Skase will run rings around Australian authorities is somewhat breathtaking.

Who does Mr Kerr think he is? He goes on and says that we are wasting our money. He does not seem to understand—the proceedings in Spain are between the Spanish government and Mr Skase. We are not funding these proceedings. It is just ludicrous. He does not even understand that much. As to the suggestion that new charges should be laid, Mr Skase would have to commit some new offences. You cannot charge people with something for the fun of it. New charges were laid in 1997, I think, but they related to the same criminal conduct. There can be no new extradition proceedings—Mr Lavarch, as Attorney-General, clearly understood that. We are not wasting taxpayers' money, and Mr Skase is not running rings around Australian authorities. The only upsetting thing is that we have headlines like `Chase for Skase Waste of Money' in the Majorca Daily Bulletin. That undermines the confidence of Spanish authorities in our determination to chase Skase, and it gives a boost to Mr Skase and to all his clan of hangers-on. My view is that Mr Beazley should bite the bullet now and sack Mr Kerr, because he does not understand his job.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the minister aware that, according to his affidavit to the Federal Court, Mr Moore-Wilton concluded in February this year that all departmental secretaries were performing sufficiently well to maintain their positions and receive their 40 per cent salary increases? Is he aware that Mr Moore-Wilton reached this conclusion following discussions with the Minister for Defence and with the concurrence of the Prime Minister? How is it that Mr Moore-Wilton's affidavit shows that Minister Moore indicated his dissatisfaction with Mr Barratt as early as January this year? How is it that Mr Moore-Wilton was able to tell a meeting of departmental secretaries in March this year that no minister was seeking the replacement of their current secretary? Given that Mr Moore-Wilton's own statement to the court details this totally incompatible series of representations, what possible credibility can any of his recommendations ever have on the assessment of the performance and tenure of departmental secretaries?

—No, I have not been trawling through the affidavits filed in the Federal Court. But I have been reflecting overnight on the question asked by Senator Faulkner yesterday. Yesterday's question was based on what Senator Faulkner alleged to be an affidavit of Mr Barratt filed in court, the proceedings of which are current. Today's question relies upon what purports to be an affidavit filed by Mr Max Moore-Wilton in that court proceeding also. I think it is inappropriate for us to speculate on matters arising out of the proceedings that are currently taking place. The more I think about it, the more I think it is totally inappropriate for us to contribute directly or indirectly.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. It may be that Senator Hill does not want to speculate upon these issues. He is entitled to a personal view, but I would ask you to rule that he is required to answer the question that I have directed to him. He is well aware of the issue of the parliamentary sub judice convention, as are all senators in this chamber. He is well aware that that convention is to safeguard legal proceedings from being prejudiced by anything said under privilege. Such a danger of influencing a case is realistic only where comments could influence a juror or a witness. There are no jurors in the Barratt case—even Senator Hill would know that. It is being heard by a judge only—Senator Hill probably knows that—and judges are unlikely to be influenced by parliamentary debate.
—This is a very long point of order, Senator.

—It is, Madam President, but it is an important one, because he is trying to duck the question. As I understand it, witnesses have concluded giving evidence in this case. I would ask you, Madam President, to direct him to answer this question, as he is required to do. It is not good enough for him to speculate on these matters. He is required to answer them in accordance with the conventions and forms of this place.

—There is no point of order. In answering the question, the minister has not raised the question of sub judice as a reason for dealing with the answer to the question. He is answering the question and I cannot direct him as to how he deals with it. He must be relevant to the topic which has been put to him and it is for him to answer that as he sees fit. He has not raised the sub judice question. It would not be relevant if he did, as you have pointed out, but he did not raise it.

—As I said, in contrast to Senator Faulkner, I have not been trawling through affidavits filed in the Federal Court that are the subject of current proceedings. The question asked by Senator Faulkner is based upon his assertion that there is an affidavit to a certain effect. I do not know whether that is the case. It would be speculative of me to answer. Furthermore, I think it is also inappropriate to be dealing with these matters whilst the court case is on foot. If Senator Faulkner wishes to make some political point arising out of legal proceedings, it seems to me that the appropriate time to do that is after the proceedings have been completed, not when the proceedings are in process.
—You're claiming sub judice, are you?
—Senator Schacht, it is not your question and you do not have the call.
—I am just helping things along.
—Senator Faulkner is perfectly capable of pursuing his own question.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Hill whether he would acknowledge the very significant public interest that exists in the Barratt sacking issue, given the light that it sheds on the government that Senator Hill is a member of and the government's handling of public administration responsibilities at the highest level. Now that Mr Barratt has been so unceremoniously dumped by Mr Moore and his former friend the Prime Minister on the basis of underperformance, what does this episode say for the competence of Mr Moore-Wilton and the rigour of his much vaunted lemon hunt review process? Will Mr Moore-Wilton have the responsibility for making recommendations to the Prime Minister in respect of the new performance bonuses for secretaries? In light of the Barratt fiasco, what credibility could any of Mr Moore-Wilton's recommendations have? (Time expired)

—The question as I understood it, if I could repeat it in a brief form, was: does the government require high standards of its senior public servants? The answer is yes; it requires demanding and high standards, and it requires that of all secretaries to departments, as of all public servants. If it does not receive performance that it regards to be satisfactory, it will take appropriate action.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. Can the minister explain to the Senate why the federal government has delayed in fully implementing the National Pollutant Inventory? If there has been a delay in compiling industry handbooks, why cannot those which have been completed be released so that at least some reporting can begin in line with the original timetable? Is it correct that this delay will also mean that companies will still not have to report highly toxic substances, such as dioxins and hydrochloric acid? Will there also be a delay in the planned review of the operation and scope of the National Pollutant Inventory? Don't all Australians have a right to information now on the release of pollutants into the environment, not in four years time?

—I thank the honourable senator for his question. For most industries affected, as I recall, workbooks have been completed and the gathering of information for the reporting process has already taken place. In some industries it has not because the workbooks, as has been mentioned by the honourable senator, have not been completed. That is because, as it turned out—and this is obviously a new experience for Australia—many more workbooks were necessary than was appreciated and the production of those books turned out to be a much more complicated and demanding process than anticipated. The government's desire is to have the process side of the NPI put in place as quickly as possible so that full reporting can take place.

answer.para: I regret the fact that there will be some delay in some sectors as a result of these matters. This government put the NPI in place and we are committed to it. We believe that the public has a right to know and that the NPI will therefore contribute to better public knowledge and community decision making in this regard. In its original concept, the scope of the NPI was designed to be reviewed and it is still to be reviewed in scope—and the honourable senator will know some of those questions, such as whether or not transfers should be included. There is also the issue as to when the expanded list of substances should come into effect. So there are to be reviews and a review is under way. It is taking a little longer than we would have hoped, but it will work. It will provide the community with information that we believe it has a right to know and it will obviously be appreciated by that community, which has concerns about quality matters.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. The minister indicated that there are to be reviews; I would be pleased if he could indicate when those reviews will occur. Is it not the case that the NPI was seen by Australia and agreed to by Australia as a necessary part of our commitment to implement agenda 21 from the environment summit in Rio? The minister has just indicated that part of the review was to look at whether or not the transfer of wastes should be added to the NPI. How is it possible to have an effective NPI in accordance with our international commitments without including waste transfers? Won't this delay that has occurred further delay the possibility of including waste transfers in our overall National Pollutant Inventory, in accordance with the commitments we have given to the international community as well as the Australian community?

—I think the best course of action would be if I got a full brief for Senator Bartlett on the whole process and timetable. There were clearly differences of view about how many substances should be included. We relied upon gains, I might say, from the experiences of those countries that have been down the path of an NPI before us. The issues of transfer have also been debated extensively internationally. One of the arguments for not including transfers was that they are accounted for otherwise within state regulatory processes.

answer.para: But, accepting that the honourable senator is obviously serious about the detail of this matter, I will get him the full brief which he can consider. If he has any ideas or wants to assist us in our further development of this program, we would be pleased to receive that support, as we have been to receive the support of the Australian Democrats in a number of environmental matters in recent times.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister aware of Mr Downer's statement yesterday that he did not notice a cable regarding the issue of peacemaking operations in East Timor because `no minister could read 100,000 cables'? Isn't it a fact that this was actually a category B cable, indicating an important matter requiring urgent attention and action? Doesn't the minister's office receive only 20 to 30 of these cables a day? Is the minister expecting us to believe that no-one in the department ever thought to draw the minister's attention to this high priority cable? Is the minister expecting us to believe that the department never saw fit to provide him with a written brief on the implications for Australia of such a significant development? Is the minister expecting us to believe that the department provided him with no advice or options on the issues arising out of the cable?
—Here's your chance, Robert.
—I'm a Downer supporter; I think he's doing a brilliant job, Senator.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Hill has just misled the parliament.
—There is no point of order.

—The only misleading I know of today is Senator Faulkner misleading Mike Seccombe—and Graham Richardson, I am sorry, but we can understand that because they were not the best of friends in the old days.

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Good mates after this morning, are you? He might not be when he realises that you misled him. In terms of Senator Ray's question, I would have thought that 20 to 30 cables in itself on top of all of the—
—This is going to war stuff.

—But the problem is, Senator Bolkus, apparently what was in the cable was inconsistent with what the Americans said publicly yesterday, in any event. It would seem that what Mr Downer was saying was consistent with the public statements of the United States. Senator Ray seems to be saying that it is a hanging offence for Mr Downer not to have read and absorbed 20 to 30 cables a day on top of all his other workload.
—We used to do that!

interjection.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The sorts of breaches of standing orders going on at present on both sides are unacceptable and make it very difficult for anybody to hear what is being said.

interjection.para: Senator Alston interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Alston, I am speaking. There is an appropriate time to debate this matter and it can be done after question time, but Senator Hill is entitled to the call at present.

interjection.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr, I have just spoken about disorderly conduct.

—We have learnt something today. We have wondered for some time why Senator Cook was so ineffective; we now know that it was because he spent all day reading cables. But I think Senator Ray has made the point himself: 20 to 30 cables a day, plus he expects briefing notes on each of those cables, on top of the total workload is asking a great deal. So one slip, one failure to read one part of one cable on one occasion in my view is not a hanging offence.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. How do we know that this is the one failure? The real point of the question, Senator Hill, is why Mr Downer's staff or Mr Downer's department did not identify this cable as a very significant one? Anyone who looks at the subject matter of American marines going into East Timor post plebiscite would regard this as a very serious issue with implications for Australia. Why didn't the department contact Mr Downer on this? Why didn't Mr Downer's staff draw his attention to it? On how many other occasions—we are entitled to know—has similar material slipped through the net because of poor procedures?

—Senator Ray is now asking me to speculate, which is obviously inappropriate; nevertheless, taking the hook—having a go, as they say—it might well be because it would seem that what was in the cable was inconsistent not only with public statements but also with Mr Downer's understanding from his many meetings and other written materials on the very same matter.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Can the minister inform the Senate of the measures which are being taken to ensure the government's Telstra 2 share offer is accessible to all Australians?

—Thank you, Senator Brownhill, for that important question. The government announced on 25 July this year the Telstra 2 offer, an offer which has the potential to include a great number of Australians in owning shares. It is a policy of this government that Australians should regard the dream of owning one's home alongside owning shares. What we have done in this offer is make available to those people who want to pre-register by 16 August this year the opportunity to purchase 400 shares in Telstra. They have the option to put themselves forward for the purchase of even more shares. Existing Telstra shareholders are not required to pre-register, and they will have the opportunity to even further their ownership of Telstra shares.

answer.para: The important aspect of this matter is the question of accessibility. We have written 9.6 million letters to all those who are currently Telstra fixed line customers, to those who registered for the first Telstra offer and did not purchase shares and to all of the brokers' clients. That is a very large mail-out indeed, and it is aimed at including all Australians, giving them the chance to participate in this venture. Anyone who wishes to pre-register can do so over the phone by calling the free call number 1800 181818.

talk.start.para: —What are you reading now, Chris—Telstra's ad?
—Yes, it is an ad. It is a chance to let Australians have a go at becoming part owners in a great Australian company. If this is an ad, so be it.

answer.para: We are also endeavouring to get to those various sectors of the community which do not have English as a first language. We have share offers available in languages such as Chinese, Greek, Italian, Vietnamese and Arabic. We have a translation service available on 131450 for those people who do have trouble with the English language and we also have information being extensively publicised to the indigenous community via three ATSI newspapers and Imparja TV.

It is very important that this offer be accessible by all Australians. We also have braille versions of a pre-registration letter, which has been sent out to many Australians. We are indicating by this that we are a government that wants as many Australians as possible to participate in this second offer of Telstra shares. It is good news for Australia and good news for Australians.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—The Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education References Committee, by letter dated 2 August 1999, has raised a matter of privilege under standing order 81. The committee believes that penalties have been imposed upon a witness in consequence of his giving evidence to the committee. The committee's belief is supported by documents attached to its letter, which indicate that action has been taken against the person concerned in direct consequence of his evidence.

interjection.para: Past reports by the Committee of Privileges and determinations by the Senate in relation to those reports have indicated that it is a contempt of the Senate to inflict penalties upon a witness in consequence of their evidence, regardless of whether those penalties would otherwise be lawful.
