We have a situation where the Prime Minister has probably snowed the genuinely republican members of his own frontbench and his own party room. He has dudded genuine republicans throughout Australia in the framing of the referendum questions. I believe a poll like the AC Nielsen poll has outed the Prime Minister on this issue. I would urge members of the coalition in the Senate, and perhaps I should include the Australian Democrats in this—they are emerging coalition partners; I think that is a fair thing to say—

talk.start.para: —At least we're not the fourth faction of the ALP!

—I would urge the coalition parties to consider the results of the Nielsen poll and the very clear message it contains about the motives and manipulations of Prime Minister John Howard. I say to Senator Woodley: if only you would be so honourable as to be the fourth faction of the Labor Party, you would also be welcome. The Prime Minister should not be allowed to dictate the result of constitutional reform. He should not be allowed to do it in the shabby and deceptive way that he has. We are going to work as actively as we can against these tactics.

speech.para: The bipartisan joint select committee made a clear compromise recommendation on the long title. It is a compromise that is fair to all. In my view, to give in to the tactics of the Prime Minister would be absolutely unacceptable. Further compromise would mean giving in to the Prime Minister's tactics and the tactics of his monarchist supporters. The Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, has often spoken of his own passion for the republic. I reckon that is a passion that is a feature of the Labor Party as a whole. It reflects the view of the significant majority of Australians. We also passionately believe all Australians deserve to be presented with a fair and accurate referendum question. We are committed to ensuring that a proper choice is put before the people, and I would urge all senators to support the amended long title that I have moved on behalf of the opposition.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Greens are also moving an identical amendment. Therefore much of what Senator Faulkner had to say applies. The hour is late, so I am not going over that territory again. This amendment is the outcome of a committee that looked at it very closely and is one that we support. I endorse the amendment.

—The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the amendment. However, I wish to put on record an acknowledgment of the joint select committee's good work, not only in its advisory report but also in its recommendation that is before us. I signed off on that recommendation. I certainly felt that the wording was acceptable and worthy, but the amendment before us does not have the total support of my Democrat colleagues. We believe that the following amendment will provide an equally simple and accurate, but we think also a new and improved, version in this debate.

—I want to go through a little bit of history in respect of the opposition's amendment and Senator Brown's amendment, and also to reflect for a moment on the Democrat amendment. We are concerned here about getting a real outcome. Our concern is that there has been a long period of consultation and development of the amendment that both the Labor Party and the Greens put up today. It is the amendment that basically came from the bipartisan joint parliamentary committee. It reflects both the concerns and the desire of that committee—the desire being to get a fair reflection of the process.

speech.para: Before going back to analyse what we have done as a committee, can I say to the Democrats that this debate will obviously go on until the morning—we have got only three minutes to go and I am sure that other people want to speak in respect of this—but I am sure that the chamber would like to be apprised of how serious you are in respect of your amendment. If you are not going to support the Labor amendment and the Greens amendment then, as you of course have your own, you can tell us how good that is. We do not want to be victims of a charade here. We do not want to be taken down the garden path by the Democrats and then be told, `Oh, we were not really serious. The Prime Minister does not like it. Therefore we will not persist with it.' The Prime Minister has not liked quite a number of things about this process, all the way through. He did not in fact like having the process. He is obviously no republican.

What we have at this stage of the debate is a Prime Minister who is saying to us, `Either take what I want or take nothing at all.' We should make him blink. The Senate should stand up and say, `Prime Minister, your proposal is not fair. It is not balanced against fairness in outcome in this debate.' But we do not want to be led by the Democrats, who in one sense I suppose, if you look at the statements over the last 24 hours, have graduated from being fairies at the bottom of the garden to developing their own child-care centre down there when it comes to negotiations.

talk.start.para: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Murray, you may laugh but, if you are serious about your proposal, do not tell us that you are going to be serious about it for 24 hours. If we are going to support it as a second best to ours, we want to know that you are prepared to take the Prime Minister on in respect of it. We also need you to know that on a number of occasions so far he has said, `No, this is not on'—but he has had to move in the interests of fairness and in response to public reaction. He looks very much like a spoiler when he says, `You will take what I give you and nothing else.' He has said that consistently through this debate; he says it again now. But what should be motivating you, as Democrats, and also the whole chamber, is how we get a fair and balanced question, and how we persist with it. As I said, the messages were somewhat mixed last night as to how serious the Democrats were in respect of their amendment. For instance, we are not going to be victims of a charade, if we have to support second best, and find ourselves supporting the Democrat amendment and then being told by the Democrats, `Well, the Prime Minister has said all or nothing and he may defer the referendum.' This issue is not the plaything of this Prime Minister, and that is a view that the public has expressed time after time in reaction to the way that he has played this debate.

speech.para: Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak about an exceptional young policeman who died tragically last week in the Northern Territory: Sergeant Glen Huitson. By all accounts he was a remarkable person with a great capacity for giving and caring, and a strong love of life. He was the sort of person who holds a community together and makes it strong and good. Now, unfortunately, he has been lost to us. On Tuesday, 3 August at 11.45 a.m., Sergeant Glen Huitson was shot by a gunman in a cowardly attack while manning a roadblock on the Stuart Highway. He died in Royal Darwin Hospital approximately an hour after the shooting and is survived by his wife, Lisa, and their two children, Joseph, aged 2, and Ruby, aged six months.

speech.para: Sergeant Huitson was based at Adelaide River, a small and important community on the Stuart Highway, approximately 100 kilometres from Darwin. He had served in Alice Springs, Nauiyu Nambiyu and other communities throughout the Northern Territory, and was respected as a good cop who looked after people in his community with a gentle but firm hand. Sergeant Huitson was at the forefront of active policing with all its rewards and dangers. He was given a full police funeral on Saturday morning at St Mary's Cathedral in Darwin. As a mark of recognition and respect, over 2,000 people—family, friends, fellow officers and the general public—attended the funeral of this most well-known and loved man.

For such a fine young man to have died in such a senseless attack is an absolute tragedy which now impacts so cruelly on his family, colleagues and the community. Sergeant Huitson had everything in life to live for, but he gave his life for the community of the Northern Territory doing his duty as a police officer. He was a brave man. In February of this year, without drawing his gun and with no lives being lost, Sergeant Huitson disarmed a drug-crazed gunman who had hijacked a tourist bus. His medal of valour for this extraordinary act of heroism was presented at his funeral to his widow, Lisa, by the Police Commissioner in a most moving ceremony.

This tragic event has shocked the people of the Northern Territory to the core. It has made many reflect on the sacrifices that our police make in the interests of the public good and the risks they are called on to face courageously in carrying out their duty. This young officer and his family have made the ultimate sacrifice for the community. Sergeant Huitson was an exceptional police officer with an outstanding career to date and so much to look forward to. Most importantly, he was a husband, a father, a son, a brother and a friend to so many. His great loss is shared by the whole Northern Territory community. He will be missed.

subdebateinfo.title: Health: Funding for Smoking Prevention Programs
Huitson, Sergeant Glen

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak tonight about smoking, heart disease and, in particular, the Northern Territory government's lack of commitment to funding prevention programs. Two weeks ago the Heart Foundation, when celebrating its 40th birthday, praised the generosity of the Australian people, whose donations have greatly assisted the foundation in its mission of reducing heart disease in our community. The research carried out by the Heart Foundation provides important information which can be used in the fight against heart disease, and this information is often most powerfully channelled through the medium of television and video.

speech.para: Three months ago, during National Heart Week, I had the pleasure of attending the launch of a video called Listen to your heart. This short video, produced by the Heart Foundation in Darwin, tackles the very serious level of heart disease in Australia's indigenous community. The video with its simple messages and humour, using boxer James Swan as a role model, was impressive, and I congratulate both the Heart Foundation and those who were involved in producing the video on the results of their efforts. The aim of the video is to promote the reduction of lifestyle factors which increase the risk of heart disease and to encourage people to give up smoking, to adopt healthy eating patterns and to get more exercise. The distribution of this video to Aboriginal communities will be a small but important step in the effort to reduce heart disease in our indigenous communities.

At its launch, the video was introduced by the Director of the Northern Territory Heart Foundation, Dr Chris Burns. Dr Burns told the assembled crowd that heart disease and stroke had reached epidemic proportions in Australia's indigenous community. In this context, he acknowledged that the video was a small but important contribution towards reducing heart disease amongst indigenous people. He also talked about the higher prevalence of juvenile smoking in the Northern Territory and pointed to the alarming differences between national and Territory rates of heart disease. The rate of heart disease in the Northern Territory is 1½ times the national average. But the facts on indigenous heart disease rates are particularly frightening. Indigenous Australians between the ages of 25 and 64 have seven to nine times greater risk of death from heart disease and stroke than other Australians. Unfortunately, around 40 per cent of all heart attacks and strokes cannot be fully explained by the risk factors we already know about, so some aspects of heart disease are still puzzling medical scientists.

However, the message that came through from both Dr Burns and the video was loud and clear: when it comes to heart disease, prevention is better than cure. Some people might see this as a tired old cliche, a fact that is so blindingly obvious that it is barely worth wasting breath on. We believe that people have long since got the message—but perhaps not. Dr Burns went on to share some more statistics about rates of heart disease in the Territory and in Australia's indigenous community which might seem even more shocking than the ones I have already mentioned. Most people now know that smoking increas es the risk of several serious health conditions, including heart disease. The real message is getting people to stop as well as preventing young Australians from starting to smoke in the first place. This involves putting in place a range of programs which deter young people from starting to smoke and different strategies aimed at helping people to quit the habit.

Governments in all states have recognised this by committing funds to smoking prevention and cessation programs. Yet the Northern Territory government has shown less commitment to funding tobacco programs than any other state or territory government. Given the high incidence of smoking-related illness in the Northern Territory, this is particularly disturbing. It is astonishing that, while the Northern Territory government receives an estimated $48 million in revenue from tobacco, it spends only $500,000 of this on smoking prevention programs. What is worse is that it has shown little interest in policing the sale of tobacco to juveniles. It was recently revealed that, since legislation prohibiting the sale of tobacco was introduced, there has been only one such charge. The health minister's reluctance to see there is a need for more resources to police the sale of tobacco to juveniles is particularly concerning, given reports that smoking prevalence is growing amongst Territory schoolchildren.

The Northern Territory government's shameful record on tobacco control reached its peak this year when it received the Australian Medical Association's Dirty Ashtray Award. It managed to achieve this embarrassing title by scoring zero for performance on a range of tobacco control measures. These included a zero for restrictions on smoking in outdoor public places, a zero for point of sale advertising restrictions, a zero for regulation of nicotine and a zero for industry accountability.

During National Heart Week, the Northern Territory Health Minister, Steve Dunham, was asked on radio about the level of government spending on smoking prevention programs. His response was stunningly evasive. He insisted that spending on smoking prevention was not limited to half a million dollars. Why? Because the Northern Territory government spends millions of dollars on hospital treatment of people with smoking related illnesses. Even the interviewer seemed amazed that the health minister could attempt to dodge the real issue in such an obvious way. The point of smoking prevention programs is to stop heart disease developing in the first place. The minister's claim that money spent on hospital treatment of smoking related illness could in any way be considered as money spent on smoking prevention is ridiculous.

The Country-Liberal government have talked a lot recently about the overburdened public hospital system and the cost of providing health services in the Northern Territory. In fact, they were so concerned about the cost of hospital care that they recently considered privatising the entire public hospital system. But primary prevention could go a long way to relieving the burden on the public hospital system. It would go a long way to preventing people from developing the diseases which put them in hospital in the first place. But when it comes to divvying up the government's spoils from people's unhealthy habits, primary prevention barely gets a look in; the purse strings seem to be drawn very tightly.

It is a pity that the attention currently being given to illicit drugs seems to have diverted the attention of governments away from the issue of tobacco smoking and its health effects. We should not forget that tobacco is a dangerous and addictive drug, claiming many more lives than either marijuana or heroin. In particular, heart disease is claiming more lives in the Northern Territory than anywhere else in Australia and the association with smoking is clear. The Northern Territory health department's own figures prove this. In the Northern Territory, smoking has been shown to double the risk of heart disease. With 35 per cent of the population smoking, much higher than the national average of 25 per cent, smoking cessation should be treated as a serious public health issue and funded accordingly. It is high time the Country-Liberal government used more of the bounty it reaps from tobacco to prevent this dangerous habit. If the Northern Territory govern ment is serious about reducing the level of preventable chronic disease and death associated with smoking, it should do the right thing and commit the resources to smoking prevention and tobacco regulation.

In closing, I would like to reiterate the words of my colleague from the Northern Territory Senator Grant Tambling in relation to Sergeant Huitson's death in the previous fortnight. The words that Senator Grant Tambling said are true: it has shocked the Territory community. Along with many others, I attended Sergeant Huitson's funeral last Saturday. The police community is a big family. It is not only his immediate family that were most upset by his death but every member of the police force and most members of the community in the Territory. I congratulate Grant for putting on record the efforts that Glen Huitson made to the Territory and I would also like to put on record my sympathy for his family and my heartfelt thanks for the contribution he made to the Territory during his short life.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak on the issue of drugs in schools. I have noticed with interest Senator Tierney's contribution to the drugs debate. Today he criticised the terminology of `soft' drugs and `recreational' drugs. While these terms are flawed, I do not think the solution is to portray all drugs as equally bad and dangerous. Marijuana is not heroin, is not ecstasy, is not speed, is not LSD. Yes, marijuana can cause schizophrenia, it would seem, but let us not exaggerate the risks. Hyping up the dangers is no match for the attraction that illicit drugs exert through popular culture.

speech.para: Brian McConnell of Families and Friends for Drug Law Reform has warned that schoolchildren need the facts about drugs without exaggeration, embellishment or hype. As we know, the Prime Minister advocates zero tolerance of illicit drugs in schools. What will this mean in terms of the $18 million National Drug Education Strategy? Can any school based harm minimisation initiatives coexist with this aim?

Hardly any of the $18 million has been spent so far. A draft paper has been produced, but that is about it. The government has said fighting drugs in schools is a priority, yet it has spent less than a seventh of the amount allocated for the strategy for 1998-99. In response to the strategy, Mr McConnell cited the UK instance of a 10-year-old boy bringing marijuana to his school's `show and tell'. Should this boy have been expelled from school? Prime Minister Howard has urged schools to expel any student using illegal drugs. Perhaps the marijuana came from the boy's parents. This incident neatly illustrates the point that, rather than being readily identifiable deviants, cannabis users often come from all walks of life. They are parents, employees, executives, teachers, stockbrokers, newsreaders, our favourite musicians and even politicians. Widespread usage is exactly why we cannot get through to children on a `just say no' message alone.

We are far more comfortable with the idea that alcoholics are often respected members of society holding down good jobs and bringing up children. It does not mean we condone the addiction. Alcohol is implicated in family violence and, with tobacco, accounts for far more deaths and disease than illicit drugs. Yet, legal drugs are not addressed in the National Drug Education Strategy. We risk being thought of as hypocrites if we lecture children on the dangers of illegal drugs but do not address legal drugs. Drug use is everywhere in popular culture. We expect to whack emotional problems on the head with a new pill, whether it is viagra or a new range of drugs to treat social disorders. There is an expectation that we will find a pill for every problem.

Recent findings by the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicate that more than 40,000 children under 14 are on antidepressants. Some of these are as young as four. I would love to know what causes children this young to be depressed and what we might be able to do about it. In no way do I want to criticise medical solutions to child depression or attention deficit disorder and so on, but we do need to be vigilant in monitoring trends in diagnosis and usage and to always look for preventative measures. Depression is endemic, with the World Health Organisation expecting it will eventually overtake heart disease as the world's biggest killer.

We need a debate on how we can help young people develop the resilience they need to negotiate an increasingly tough, complex world. A recent Queensland study of children in detention showed that most have a history of hard drinking and illicit drug use by the age of 15 and inject amphetamines and heroin at 40 times the rate of others their age. They begin using tobacco at the age of 10, alcohol and cannabis at 11, drank in excess of 10 standard drinks at a session and had a 50 per cent chance of having used sedatives or amphetamines. Forty per cent of those surveyed identified as Aboriginal and 90 per cent were male.

A recent mental health week campaign featured a range of celebrities exercising their mental health by reading, fishing and playing sport. It was very well intended, but I doubt that anyone seeing those billboards would have come away with a different perspective on their own mental health. In a society with widening gaps between the haves and the have-nots, it seems strange to me that ordinary people are expected to take a message from comparing themselves with celebrities.

My office recently came in contact with a high school student who had some strong ideas on drug education that I think are worth repeating here. She is not on a youth roundtable or any other organisation that filters the opinions of young people to make them fit for politicians' consumption. She is an ordinary student at a school that is well regarded in the community, but there cannabis is rife, with children as young as year 7 desperate to start smoking. Joints are sometimes laced with heroin and speed, something I doubt even school leavers five or 10 years ago had to contend with. Kids deal drugs at this school. Drug education sessions, she said, were a joke because the students usually knew more than the teachers.

Most students did not know there was the school counsellor, but in any case counselling was stigmatised. This young woman wished students could visit a counsellor off the premises to ensure privacy. There were also concerns that anything said to a counsellor would be passed on to teachers or parents. Professor David Penington's report argues against a mandatory reporting approach such as exists in New South Wales because such a requirement undermines the work of school counsellors. Professor Penington was criticised by Senator Tierney today for being permissive. This girl and her friends want to know the real risks of schizophrenia from marijuana use. And she talked of a crisis in self-esteem among kids at the school. She wants to be taught skills to negotiate the world instead of feeling like a passive consumer of education. There is a self-esteem movement of sorts in American schools, and I have been approached by constituents who argue that self-esteem education should be in schools. My only caution is that such education cannot be expected to fill the vacuum created by rising youth unemployment, the cost of further education, the expectation that young people should be dependent on their parents financially until the age of 25 and the general narrowing of life opportunities.

This girl also wanted to know what to do in a drug related crisis. She said, `We don't want to be told it's wrong; we want to know how to deal with it.' She described being in a group of friends, one of whom had an adverse reaction to an illegal drug. As her lips turned blue, the rest of the group kept a lid on their panic, hoping she would come to. Luckily, she did, but what would happen if things had turned out differently? Clearly, a just say no approach on its own is not up to these challenges. Obviously we need to reassess punitive attitudes when they get in the way of young people seeking help. This is the principle that is emphasised by Professor Penington's research. We can wring our hands all we like at the idea of 15-year-olds taking drugs, but what are we going to do about it? The National Drug Education Strategy unfortunately seems unrealistic with its aim of no illicit drugs in schools. Mr McConnell from Family and Friends for Drug Law Reform notes:
Our most secure institutions, gaols, do not stop inmates from obtaining or using drugs. It is therefore unrealistic for less secure institutions such as schools to be able to do it.

What do we do about those kids who instead of saying no just say yes? Risk taking is a part of adolescence. It is unfortunate that the palette of substances available these days is so much more varied. Inevitably, some children will experiment with drugs. For some it will just be a phase, and for others it will be just the start of their problems. I think we must also acknowledge that children growing up in abusive homes will often turn to drugs to mask their suffering. Schools can be the lifeline for children in such circumstances. We must not turn them into yet another agent of punishment. Professor Penington has warned that expulsion increases the risk of children moving to harder drugs and addiction. The overriding aim of any strategy, he says, is to keep children at school. In April, the Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett, told the National Press Club:

What sort of message do they get if you just say throw them out so they're denied education? If you're talking about users, I'd much rather know who they are and help them rather than piling further pressures on their shoulders and ridicule and just throwing them back to their parents who in most cases won't have known their child was taking drugs or won't be able to handle it because they themselves don't know enough about the issue.

We need to listen to young people's stories about drugs and accept that even very young people may have their own stories. Perhaps we need to defer judgment as we listen to those stories and perhaps we need to come up with more questions than statements.

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Living Standards

talk.start.para: —A matter of significant concern to all of us who care deeply about the direction in which Australia is heading is the growing disparity in living conditions between those who live in rural and regional areas of Australia and those who live in our cities. The Howard government has achieved much in its first and second terms to get the macro settings right for all Australians irrespective of where they live. I refer briefly to the reduction of the budget deficit, historically low inflation and interest rates, employment coming down at least in the cities, industrial relations reforms and restructuring and, as we are about to see, a new tax system that should be of great benefit to regional Australia.

speech.para: These achievements are very important in making Australia economically viable both for job and wealth creation and for prosperity for the people. However, it is apparent to me and indeed many others that there are substantial differences in living standards in some parts of Australian society, that there are some Australians who have less opportunity to better themselves than others. Unfortunately, over successive decades rural and regional Australia has found itself increasingly disenfranchised from the overall prosperity of our nation.

As someone born and bred in the country, the concerns of regional Australia have always been a focus of my attention. During the last parliamentary recess, I conducted the first of a number of regional visits in my home state of New South Wales. It was a fact-finding mission, if you like, designed to better understand the day-to-day difficulties which people living outside the metropolitan areas face. Over a period of two weeks I met with local community groups in Cowra, Young, Eden, Bega, Cooma, the Southern Highlands, Armidale, Tamworth, Maitland, Newcastle and on the Central Coast. In Eden and Cooma I was joined by my friend and colleague Senator Bill Heffernan.

I met with representatives from a number of primary industries—poultry, pork, dairy and lamb—as well as stone fruit and vegetable producers and croppers. I met with employers and employees in small and medium sized businesses, largely those involved in manufacturing and food processing. I met with local councillors of all political persuasions, all of them—like their city counterparts—struggling to provide the best possible service to their constituents, but—unlike their city counterparts—struggling to overcome the relative tyranny of distance when providing services for a dwindling and sparsely settled population. What struck me most of all was that I had been reintroduced to a breed of Australian quite different from the city folk, a breed made more resilient due to ongoing hardship. They were filled with self-determination.

What also struck me—and struck me hard—is that successive governments at both a state and federal level have let regional Australia down by failing to develop a coherent strategy to identify the opportunities for regional growth. The need for such a strategy is great. The social and economic indicators of regional Australia are profoundly atypical from the national average. I mention higher than average levels of unemployment, lower than average weekly income, higher than average rates of increasing drug abuse and higher than average rates of adult suicide, with youth suicide, perhaps the most tragic statistic of all, up to 13 times the national average. Indeed, the day I arrived in Eden some of the people I was meeting with were forced to leave early to go to the funeral of a young mother who had killed herself following the loss of her job at the Eden tuna cannery.

Access to health, education and community services is also far more limited in non-metropolitan areas, with up to a two-month waiting list for a consultation with a GP. Just to give the Senate some idea of what this really means, when I was in Armidale I was advised that the one doctor permitted to prescribe methadone to patients participating in the methadone program was retiring in six weeks time—and that doctor was in Tamworth. No replacement has been found, which means that patients will be forced to go to Grafton for the nearest doctor able to prescribe their treatment. These are people obviously in a very fragile state who are trying to stabilise a drug habit. Since each treatment lasts only eight weeks, patients will be required to make a seven- to eight-hour round journey every two months just to remain on the methadone program. Considering the rate of drug abuse is high in regional Australia and that drug related crime in regional Australia has reached unprecedented levels, such poor access to health services will only exacerbate the problem.

Finally, in political terms 33 of the 37 poorest federal electorates in Australia are rural. However, despite the obvious social and economic difficulties that the groups I met faced, not one of them would ever have accepted a hand-out. That really was not what they wanted. What they did want, however, was a hand up. There have been innumerable studies carried out on the problems in regional Australia and many constructive proposals have been made to address the problems. The problems are well known but comprehensive solutions are more elusive. Whilst the marvellous economic record of the Howard government has benefits for all, the trickle down effect is slow to reach many rural areas.

The government has sought to address the loss of services in the bush with good programs, such as Networking the Nation, and also rural transaction centres and rural traineeships for doctors. One of the complaints I encountered when meeting local communities was the perception that competition policy had unfairly impacted on small communities, causing the loss of jobs and leaving small towns with a limited choice of essential services. In Cooma, Woolworths bought out its only competitor, with price rises and scaled down hours of operation the unfortunate, if inevitable, result. Whilst it must be said that just about every ill that faces rural Australia is blamed unfairly and selectively on competition policy, it is probably right that the benefits of competition do impact unevenly and that some rural communities are thus adversely affected.

Restructuring the farm cannot be done overnight. As was so succinctly pointed out to me in Cowra, a lingerie factory can change the colour of its dye in one run. To change a strain of crops and livestock takes at least one season and quite often several. Furthermore, in Tamworth it was pointed out that changing from cattle to sheep required changes to more than just the type of livestock: in order to maintain the new stock, differently configured yards have to be built, making initial start-up costs quite extensive.

Often typified as whingeing cockies, the bush is worth saving. For anyone in doubt, an interesting fact to ponder is that only seven per cent of Australians actually live and produce from the land and this mere seven per cent in fact feeds the remaining 93 per cent of our population. What was so abundantly clear from my visits is that rural and regional Australia has the capacity to regenerate itself as long as the conditions are right. Revitalising rural Australia requires at least five major coordinates.

I have referred to the macro settings. I have referred to the need to return facilities to the bush and I have also referred to the need to make sure that the benefits of competition are distributed equitably. Far too often we have not taken account of the socioeconomic impact of competition in restructuring packages that make an industry much more efficient. It also requires superior telecommunication facilities and a good skills base for our youth. Then what is required, which is the really the most difficult part, is a coordinated regional development policy. The role of government is not to impose top-down solutions but to resource communities to find their own solutions, to identify what the community is good at and what resources it has to deploy into growing viable businesses and to create new jobs.

Obviously, government has a role to provide adequate transport, energy and access to water. All these things of course are vital to regional Australia. Clearly, one size does not fit all regions. Very different circumstances apply in different areas of New South Wales and throughout Australia. However, as a senator for New South Wales, I am totally committed to understanding the concerns of my country constituents so that their needs and concerns can be better reflected in the policy process.

talk.start.para: —I would like to comment on a very disturbing report that was released yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. That report was entitled Health and welfare of Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples . It was released by both the ABS and the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. The contents of that report have been labelled by a number of Aboriginal leaders, health workers, welfare workers and politicians as a national shame.

speech.para: I will briefly go through some of the statistics that this report highlighted which, as the nation's leaders, we need to take into account in our policy deliberations. Aborigines represent only 2.1 per cent of Australia's population. Their median age is only 20 years, whereas that of the rest of the population is 34 years. This difference between median ages is no doubt due to the fact that their life expectancy is much less than that of the rest of the Australian community.

In terms of post-secondary education, the figures are 31 per cent of non-indigenous Australians and only 11 per cent of Aborigines. In terms of adult male unemployment, nine per cent of adult male Australians are unemployed, yet 27 per cent of adult male Aborigines are unemployed. In terms of home ownership or purchasing a home, 71 per cent of non-indigenous Australians are in that category, whereas only 31 per cent of Aborigines are. These problems have been highlighted by this report and, as I said, as the nation's leaders, it is up to us to try to find some solutions.

During the winter break I accompanied the shadow minister for education, Michael Lee, to a meeting with the Board of Governors of the University of Notre Dame in Broome in Western Australia. We were exposed to a different way of how we in the Labor Party—I am sure this view is shared by the government—could deal with this difficulty by starting at the beginning with that great equaliser education. At the University of Notre Dame we met committed people. They had come from all over Australia and from the United States to try to come to terms with these problems. Local communities, educators and concerned people from around the country had come together to try to offer solutions to alleviate this suffering and to try to assist people to triumph over it.

We have all heard the phrase `to fix the problem not to blame'. I think a number of people in our country have tried to blame Aborigines for the state they are in. It is very comforting, particularly in adverse times, to find a scapegoat and to blame him or her for our difficulties or problems. In Broome we have a good example in the local communities of the cultural problems which are, as I am sure a number of people know, very different from what we know as non-indigenous Australians, but these people are trying to overcome them.

During my visit I found out that it is very difficult for indigenous people to uproot and to leave their communities and relocate to any sort of learning institution. It is particularly difficult for young adult male blacks to do that. The University of Notre Dame is attempting to deal with the fact that these people have entrenched connections with their family, their land and their local community. Those roots are so strong that, if they did uproot themselves, it would lead to intolerable social alienation.

At Notre Dame I witnessed a flexible and tailored education system that allowed the local Aboriginal communities from the north-west to participate in schemes that allowed them to upgrade themselves so that they could make sure that they were no longer dependent on others, on us, and which gave them pride in raising themselves—as, no doubt, time will allow them to demonstrate. This will not be done in the short term. Changing attitudes is not like changing shirts. It will take time, patience and tolerance from us to assist the communities to lift themselves. I believe that we can do that.

Michael and I saw how these people were prepared to get involved in the education system and how they had the courage to participate. If the majority of Australians show compassion and goodwill to these people, I believe that, in one way or another, the Aboriginal people will triumph over the suffering that was demonstrated so clearly, so intolerably and so tragically in the report that was released by the ABS yesterday.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 21 April 1999:

question.para: (1) Did a separation breakdown occur at Cairns Airport on 24 March 1999 involving an Aerocommander aircraft and another aircraft on final approach for runway 15.

(2) Did the supervisor on duty at Cairns Airport at the time of this incident fail to report to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) within 48 hours as is required by the Air Navigation Act 1920.
(3) If the supervisor failed to report the incident, what action was taken by Airservices Australia (ASA) or BASI.
(4) Was Cairns air traffic control (ATC) management advised of the incident on the day that it occurred.
(5) Did ATC management advise the officer who reported the incident that the matter should not be taken any further.
(6) Did Cairns ATC management fail to take any action following the incident until 3 days later when an air safety incident report was submitted by another party.
(7) Was any action taken against the ATC responsible for the separation breakdown; if so: (a) what was the nature of the action; and (b) when did it occur.
(8) Did ASA undertake an inquiry into the separation breakdown at Cairns Airport on 24 March 1999.
(9) (a) Who undertook the investigation; and (b) what qualifications and experience did the investigator bring to the investigation into the separation breakdown.
(10) Was the investigator from another ATC unit to ensure there was no potential for local bias in the investigation; if not, why not.
(11) (a) What was the outcome of this investigation, and (b) can a copy be provided of the findings and recommendations that resulted from the investigation.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) has advised that an Electronic Safety Incident Report (ESIR) was received on 27 March 1999. On the basis of that ESIR, BASI commenced an investigation of the incident and is currently reviewing the appropriate radar and voice tapes. A copy of the final report will be forwarded when completed.

(2) Airservices has advised that the supervisor on duty was not in the aerodrome control position at the time and was therefore unable to determine if an incident had occurred. An ESIR was subsequently submitted by the Aerodrome Controller (see 6 below), and BASI has advised the ESIR was received on Saturday, 27 March 1999.
(3) BASI has advised that no action was required as an ESIR on the incident was received.
Airservices Australia has advised that:

(4) The circumstances surrounding a possible breakdown of separation was discussed at a team meeting later on 24 March. It was not possible at that meeting to determine as to whether an incident had occurred.
(5) No. The Aerodrome Controller was advised to submit an ESIR if he considered a breakdown in separation had occurred.
(6) No, as the responsible Aerodrome Controller submitted an ESIR three days later and this was investigated by Airservices.

(7) (a) Yes. The incident was discussed with the controller by the Team Leader. The investigation of the incident showed that the controller acted properly in accordance with established procedures when he observed separation decreasing between the two aircraft.
(b) Beginning of April 1999.
(8) Yes.
(9) (a) The most experienced Cairns Area Terminal Team Leader.
(b) The Team Leader has over thirty years air traffic control experience in all facets of Check Control and Standardisation. Also, he had participated in previous investigations.
(10) No. the nature of the incident was such that an investigator from another unit was not warranted.
(11)(a) The outcome of the investigation was that a brief breakdown of separation had occurred.

(b) Yes. The investigator's report and recommendations were inserted into the ESIR report which is circulated within Airservices, BASI and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. A paper on the findings and recommendations has also been provided to the Table Office.

subdebateinfo.title: National Transmission Agency: Lilydale Transmission Tower
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1010)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 May 1999:

question.para: (1) When was the decision taken to investigate possible sites for the construction of a transmission tower near Lilydale in northern Tasmania.
(2) (a) When was the decision taken to construct the tower on Browns Mountain; and (b) what processes were followed in determining the best possible site.

(3) When did the National Transmission Agency (NTA): (a) apply for permits from the Launceston Council for the construction of the road to the proposed site; and (b) engage a contractor to construct a road to the proposed site.
(4) (a) When was construction of the road commenced; (b) when was the work completed; and (c) what was the cost of the work.
(5) At what stage were the formal processes and actual construction of the Browns Mountain transmission tower site, when the NTA was privatised.
(6) What provisions has the Government made to ensure the Browns Mountain transmission tower is completed by a private operator.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Lilydale area was identified as likely to require translator facilities during planning for Band II Clearance in 1991. The National Transmission Agency (NTA) began actively considering potential sites for the establishment of the translator in late 1993/early 1994, concurrent with the commencement of ABC TV simulcast UHF transmissions from Mt Barrow, Launceston.
(2) (a) The decision to start the process of site acquisition to construct translator facilities at Browns Hill, as it is known, was taken in March 1995.

(b) Transmission planning engineers of the NTA determined potential locations for the Lilydale translator using topographical maps, and identified Browns Hill as the only site that could adequately serve Lilydale, Lilydale North, and Underwood. NTA officers then conducted a field survey of the Browns Hill site to ensure adequate signal could be received for retransmission, and to determine the optimal location on the hill for the propagation of the transmitted services.

(3) (a) The site, and the access route to the site, were surveyed for leasing and construction purposes in December 1994. Archaeological and flora surveys were conducted at the site and along the proposed access route, in accordance with a request from the Launceston City Council dated 26 February 1996.

The Australian Property Group (Department of Administrative Services) advised the NTA on 7 May 1997 that Launceston City Council had given approval for the development and that no development application was required.
(b) The NTA did not engage a contractor to construct a road to the proposed site.
(4) (a, b & c) The NTA did not construct a road to the proposed site.

(5) By 30 April 1999, when the National Transmission Network was sold, the Commonwealth had obtained the approval of Launceston City Council for the project, and had begun negotiations with the registered owner of the land for a lease.

However, the land on which the proposed Browns Hill translator is to be located has been subject to legal disputation over its ownership. This prevented the Commonwealth from finalising a lease over the proposed site and the access route. Pending the resolution of ownership issue, the NTA suspended its planning activities and did not begin any construction of the facilities.

(6) With the sale of the National Transmission Network on 30 April 1999, the national broadcasters have, for the first time, become responsible for their own transmission arrangements, and are being funded accordingly. It is now the responsibility of the ABC and the SBS to complete the negotiations for access to the site and arrange for the installation of the television services at Lilydale. The Government will provide funding to the ABC and the SBS for the Lilydale services.

Officers from the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts met with the ABC and the SBS on 7 July 1999 to discuss the steps now to be taken. The national broadcasters are treating the provision of these services as a high priority, and will obtain the necessary technical and costing information to enable the planning and implementation to commence.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 June 1999:

subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1104)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 9 June 1999:

question.para: (1) What programs and/or grants administered by the Minister's department provide assistance to people living in the federal electorate of Bass.
(2) What was the level of funding provided through these programs and grants for the 1997-98 and 1998-99 financial years.
(3) What level of funding provided through these programs and grants has been appropriated for the 1999-2000 financial year.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts administers a number of programs and/or grants which can (or have) assist(ed) people living in the federal electorate of Bass, including:

The Government makes an annual grant to the Community Broadcasting Foundation Ltd (CBF). The CBF is an independent company established by the community broadcasting sector to allocate the annual grant to community broadcasters. Community radio stations in the Bass electorate would be eligible to apply to the CBF for funding.
Networking the Nation, the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, has provided assistance to benefit people living in the electorate.

National Council for the Centenary of Federation administers a History and Education Program. The Program supports activities which encourage Australians to gain a better understanding of the processes that led to Australia's Federation, to reflect on the changes that have taken place in Australia over the past 100 years, and to look ahead to Australia's future as a nation. The Program is open to people and organisations throughout Australia and has provided assistance to benefit people living in the electorate.

The Department is administering Commonwealth Government funding assistance to the redevelopment of the historic Launceston railway workshops. Funds are being provided to develop visitor orientation and services facilities as part of the redevelopment program, with further funding being provided under the Federation Cultural and Heritage Projects (FCHP) program to fund the development of an interpretive gallery and heritage trail. The FCHP is part of the larger $1 billion Federation Fund. It is a $70m program. Applications were sought once and closed on 30 June 1998. 60 projects were chosen and no additional funding is available.

Festival organisers from the Bass electorate are eligible to apply to the Commonwealth Government's funding program for regional and community festivals, Festivals Australia, for assistance. Performing arts organisations and eligible not-for-profit organisations may apply to the Commonwealth Government's National Per forming Arts Touring Program, Playing Australia, for assistance. Similarly, eligible non profit organisations may apply to Visions of Australia, the Commonwealth Government's national touring exhibitions program.

The National Office for the Information Economy administer the Information Technology Online Program and have two projects being managed by the Tasmanian Electronic Commerce Centre, who are based in Launceston. ITOL is designed to accelerate the national adoption of electronic commerce business solutions, especially by communities of small and medium enterprises.
Every electorate in the country has been allocated $200,000 for the Federation Community Projects program. Successful application for funding will be announced in early July 1999.
(2) In relation to the electorate of Bass, funding for the 1997-98 and 1998-99 financial years is as follows:
CBF: In 1997-98 the CBF made grants valued at $11,099 to community radio stations 7LTN and 7WAY located in the electorate of Bass.
In 1998-99 the CBF made grants totalling $16,172 to 7LTN and 7WAY, this included satellite equipment nominally valued at $934.

Networking the Nation: Grants totalling $4,731,190 have been provided and an estimated $7,925,568 is being provided which will benefit people living in the electorate. Of these figures, grants totalling $1,520,000 and an estimated $1,700,000 relate to grantees within the electorate.
National Council for the Centenary of Federation: 1997-98—Nil
1998-99—Grant of $80,000 approved for Queen Victoria Museum and Gallery, Launceston.
Launceston Railway Redevelopment:
Touring Arts Programs: Festivals Australia funded two cultural projects at festivals in the Bass electorate in the 1997-98 and 1998-99 financial years:

The George Town Folk Club Inc was funded $3,500 for Bluegrass Experience at the Tamar Valley Folk Festival in Georgetown. Bluegrass bands Colcannon and Country Express performed at concerts throughout the January 1999 festival. The artists also conducted a series of guitar, harmony and instrumental arrangement workshops for the Tamar Valley community.

Top of the Tamar Regatta was funded $1,650 for Seaweed & Song at the Top of the Tamar Regatta in Georgetown. An arts program, including artists' workshops, theatre and music performances and visual arts displays were introduced to the February 1998 Festival.
Playing Australia funded two Launceston-based companies to tour their work in the 1997-98 financial year:
Stompin Youth Dance Company was funded $44,122 for a tour of Grind to the first Australian Youth Dance Festival in Darwin in October 1997.

Theatre North was funded $9,940, with an additional guarantee against loss of $18,811, for a tour of Private Lives by Melbourne Theatre Company to Hobart, Burnie and Launceston in March 1997; and a tour of Vita and Virginia by Sydney Theatre Company to Hobart and Launceston in September 1997.
Visions of Australia—Nil to electorate of Bass
Information Technology Online Program:

The Multi-Industry Procurement Project is based in the Burnie area and includes the Burnie City Council as one of its members. The project also has participation from a number of mines (Pasminco, Aberfoyle, Renison, Beaconsfield, David Mitchell) and assorted suppliers identified by the council and the mines. The ITOL grant payments for this project is $8,000 in 98-99.

The Food and Beverage Procurement Project is based in the Hobart area and includes Wrest Point Casino, Calvary Hospital, Chung Sing Provedores and the Australian Antarctic Division as project members. The ITOL grant payments for this project is $19,200 in 98-99
From the information at hand it is not possible to determine the amount of the grant money that will be received by people living in the federal electorate of Bass.
Federation Community Projects: None
(3) In relation to the electorate of Bass, funding for the 1999-2000 financial year is as follows:
CBF: The 1999-2000 grant to the CBF is $4.871m. The community broadcasting stations in the Bass electorate will be eligible to apply for funds during the year.
Networking the Nation: Tasmania was allocated $58 million of $250 million Networking the Nation program. Each year, $50m is being appropriated for the NTN trust account.

National Council for the Centenary of Federation: Grant payment to Queen Victoria Museum and Gallery of $20,000 due this financial year. Balance of grant funds is due to be paid in financial year 2000-2001.
Other funding through the History and Education Program will be dependent on successful applications in the current Round 2 and future rounds of the Program.
Launceston Railway Redevelopment:
Funding projections for the project for 1999/00 are as follows. As the project is scheduled to continue into 2000/01, estimates for this year have also been included.
The redevelopment project is estimated to cost a total of $9.5m.
Touring Arts Programs: No announcements have been made to date.
Information Technology Online Program: Multi-Industry Procurement Project—the ITOL grant payments for this project is $12,000 in 99-2000.
Food and Beverage Procurement Project—the ITOL grant payment for this project is $28,800 in 99-2000.

Federation Community Projects: program grant funds will be expended between the 1999-2000 and 2001-2002 financial years. The timing of payments is subject to the availability of funds and negotiation with individual grant recipients.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Family and Community Services: Complaints
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1139)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 23 June 1999:

question.para: (1) How many complaints were received by the department, and its predecessor, and agencies attached to the department via the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman in: (a) the 1997-98 financial year; and (b) the 1998-99 financial year to date.
(2) How many of these complaints have been resolved.
(3) How many were resolved in favour of the complainant.
(4) In how many instances did the Ombudsman make an adverse finding in relation to the department.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: In answering the honourable Senator's question, the department has sourced information from the Ombudsman's Office to ensure the consistency of data. It should be noted that the Ombudsman's data reflects the number of complaints about specific issues, not the number of complainants. The number of complainants would be less than the number of issues about which complaints have been received.

The details of complaints in respect of each of the financial years 1997-98 and 1998-99 include data in respect of all functional areas of the current department. The figures reflect, therefore, the number of complaints across the same span of departmental activities for the two financial years in question, although those functions and activities were not amalgamated into the current department until October 1998.

(1) The total number of complaints received by the department, and its predecessor, and agencies attached to the department via the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman in the: (a) 1997-98 financial year was 4,419 and (b) the 1998-99 financial year was 2,951.
(2) The number of complaints resolved for the: (a) 1997-98 financial year was 4,410; (b) and the 1998-99 financial year was 2,686.

(3) The number of complaints resolved substantially in favour of the complainant for the: (a) 1997-98 financial year was 2,193; and (b) the 1998-99 financial year was 993. The number of complaints resolved partially in favour of the complainant for the: (a) 1997-98 financial year was 2,030; and (b) the 1998-99 financial year was 1,047.
(4) During the period 1 July 1997 to 30 June 1999 the Ombudsman made one adverse finding in relation to the Child Support Agency.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Family and Community Services: Departmental Liaison Officers
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1140)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 23 June 1999:

question.para: (1) How many departmental liaison officers (DLOs) are employed in, or seconded to, the office of the Minister as at 22 June 1999.

(2) (a) What are the names of the DLOs; (b) what are their employment classifications; and (c) what duties are they assigned, that is, to which policy areas or agencies are they allocated responsibility.
(3) What was the total cost to the Department of these officers.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Three.
(2) (a) Kylee Bates, Sue Costello and Ian Sharples; (b) FaCS 2; and (c) all DLOs deal with matters relating to all policy areas and agencies within the Family and Community Services portfolio.

(3) FaCS 2 officers receive an annual salary in the range of $52,421—$60,265 plus an allowance in lieu of overtime of $11,424. In addition, the Department provides each of these officers with a mobile telephone and the use of equipment in the office (eg. personal computer, printer, photocopier and facsimile machine).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 5 July 1999:

question.para: (1) What immigration and customs arrangements apply to seafarers on foreign vessels visiting Australian ports.
(2) How long can these seafarers remain in Australia.
(3) How are the controls that limit the time foreign seafarers can remain in Australia policed.
(4) What level of resources was applied to this task in the 1996-97, 1997-98 and 1998-99 financial years.
(5) Since March 1996, how many seafarers from foreign vessels have attempted to remain in Australia.

(6) In each case: (a) what was the nationality of each seafarer; and (b) what was the flag of the foreign vessel on which they entered Australia; (c) what was the basis for their application to remain in Australia; and (d) how many applications were successful.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Under Part 1 of Schedule 9 of the Migration Regulations, crew of non-military vessels must hold an identity document or passport for entry into Australia. They have a prescribed status under regulation 2.40 and are taken to hold Special Purpose Visas (SPVs) under section 33 of the Migration Act 1958.
Under regulation 2.40 (6), a non-citizen is taken to be member of crew of a non-military vessel and hold a special purpose visa if the vessel on which he/she travel as crew:
(a) enters Australia at:
(i) a proclaimed port; or
(ii) a port other than a proclaimed port, if permission for it to do so has been given in advance
by the Australian Customs Service under section 58 of the Customs Act 1901;
(b) will depart Australia to a place outside Australia during the course of the voyage.

Under regulation 2.40 (7), crew members signing off for repatriation from Australia can be permitted to stay up to 30 days with SPVs (in practice, they are given 5 working days to leave) on the basis that the master, owner, agent or charterer of the vessel provides a letter of guarantee that the person will leave Australia within that period.

Crew members who sign off with the intention of remaining in Australia (eg for holiday or other purposes) must hold an appropriate visa before travelling to Australia as crew, or must apply at a DIMA office in Australia, after signing off, for an appropriate visa.
(2) A seafarer can remain in Australia as long as he/she remains a member of the crew of a non-military vessel (under regulation 2.40(6)) during the course of the vessel's voyage.

(3) Crew of foreign vessels must comply with the conditions of their SPV and leave Australia, as provided in regulation 2.40(6). Masters of foreign vessels are required to report any crew desertion as soon as possible before their vessels leave Australia. Foreign crew who desert their vessels will automatically become unlawful non-citizen and will be subject to detention and removal.
(4) Not available. There is no specific resource allocation for compliance activities in respect of foreign seafarers.

(5) My department does not collect statistics on seafarers who apply to remain in Australia. Statistics are collected on seafarers who desert their vessels in Australia and become unlawful non-citizens. Between March 1996 and 30 April 1999, 263 ship deserters were reported by the Australian Customs Service. Of the 148 who were located, 53 applied to remain in Australia.
(6) (a) The 53 applicants were from the following nationalities:
3 PRCH (China), 1 Hong Kong, 1 Portugal, 11 Turkey, 2 Fiji, 2 Bangladesh, 2 Egypt, 7 Iran, 1 Algeria, 2 former USSR, 1 Romania, 1 Yugoslavia, 1 UK and 18 stateless;
(b) they are recorded on the basis of their nationalities only;
(c) 5 applied under parent and spouse provisions; 8 under general residence, prospective marriage, change in circumstance and family residence provisions, and 40 applied for refugee status.
(d) 17 were approved.
